characters: CUT TO WHAT BILLY'S BEEN LOOKING AT THIS WHOLE TIME -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Static shots: A deserted locker room. Empty showers. Cinder-block tunnels lit with wire-encased lamps like in a coal mine. THREE SECURITY GUARDS watch a game on a TV. LEGEND: October 15, 2001

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We begin to hear disembodied cheering crowds and the faint voice of an announcer -

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAMAN V/O
dialogues.text: ... nobody on, two and two to Saenz - who has just three at bats in the series, and none of them hits - as he settles back in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of a tunnel, the A's empty dugout. The empty diamond. Just a couple of the floodlights are on.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAMAN V/O
dialogues.text: - Rivera looks in for the sign, he has it, the pitch, Saenz swings and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The announcer's voice and excited crowd abruptly cut off. In silence, we regard the 60,000 empty seats that wrap around the playing field ... but then see that, in fact, it's 59,999 empty seats. There's a lone figure seated in one of them. The sound snaps back on:

dialogues.speaker: STEVE LYONS V/O
dialogues.text: - a ground out to second, Thom, is not what the A's were looking for from Saenz - down by two in the ninth -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lone man in the stadium has a radio and a bag of peanuts. He seems at peace as he looks down on the empty diamond - a peace only slightly belied, perhaps, by the baseball he absently turns in a hand. He switches the radio back on -

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAMAN V/O
dialogues.text: Eric Byrnes has emerged from the dugout to bat for Menechino - 2. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns it off again. Calmly eats a peanut. Waits. Switches the radio back on -

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAMAN V/O
dialogues.text: - the A's are down to their last strike and this Yankee crowd is on its feet - Rivera squints for the sign, he has it, delivers and - Again, at the crucial moment, he cuts the radio. Waits just a few moments. Turns the radio back on -

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAMAN V/O
dialogues.text: It is bedlam in New York. The Yankees - down two games to none - have come back to win three, and the Division Series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outcome of the series seems to have no effect on Billy. He simply gets up, switches off the radio, and climbs the steps to leave. But somehow we still faintly hear, as he comes past shuttered concession stands toward an exit, the voice of one of the announcers -

dialogues.speaker: STEVE LYONS V/O
dialogues.text: This is an exceptional feat not only for New York, Thom, but for Oakland - though not the kind you can be proud of: Only once before has a team lost a Division Series after winning the first two games -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming from a small television a night security guard is watching. But when he sees Billy approaching, he quickly shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Joe, you can leave it on. It's no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's okay, I don't need to watch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard's eyes consider the baseball Billy absently turns in his hands -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Meg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and the glass window of the bar behind him - 3. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the boys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're good. Everybody's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. The security guard waits for the baseball to sail through the glass, but it doesn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night, Billy. It was a great season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone car sits in the parking lot in front of the Coliseum. We HEAR-

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: They had three times your payroll, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: You're not watching them celebrate, right? Car's off. Billy sits in the dark on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That would be, uh--

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: Pointless? Self-destructive? Masochistic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asking me to pick one?

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: What you should be doing is thinking about what an amazing job you did and how great you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be honest, right this minute I'm not thinking about either of those things. 4. 4.

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: You take a team with that payroll to the playoffs? You take the Yankees to a fifth game? I'm not even sure the better team won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were down two-love and then beat us three in a row. Trust me, the better team won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY presses a button on his portable radio and is hit with sound of sports talk radio--

dialogues.speaker: CALLER V/O
dialogues.text: --while embarrassing the entire city and making a mockery of their fans. I'm sick of this.

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: Let's go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO WHAT BILLY'S BEEN LOOKING AT THIS WHOLE TIME -
dialogues.text: Three enormous looming likenesses of the Oakland A's premiere players on floodlit banners--Jason Giambi, Johnny Damon, Jason Isringhausen.

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: Someplace they don't have a baseball team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Oakland?

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: Okay, here are the rules for tonight. You can do anything you want but you can't give any quotes to the press, go on the internet or hurt my car, we have a deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: They had three times your payroll, Billy. From the radio we've been hearing shards of "--an unprecedented choke--", "--get rid of Billy Beane--", "-- Billy Beane knows nothing about baseball--". 5. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TARA V/O
dialogues.text: How about Hawaii? I'll make a reservation someplace. The place with the turtles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I'm on my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy chucks the radio away. Gets back in the car, puts it in gear. HARD CUT TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blur of shapes and colors as we move through a crush of travelers to a Hawaiian Airlines counter where Billy and Tara check luggage. Billy's got a cell phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it Boston? You're talking to Boston? What are they offering?

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: What does it matter to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: I mean -- what does it matter since whatever it is you can't afford it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that -- since I don't know what they're offering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said we had to hurry up. 6. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott? Scott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The call's been disconnected. CUT TO: Another corridor, as Billy and Tara head toward security. Billy on the phone with Boras, continuing where they left off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they offer?

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: They offered seven and a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to be clear -- they offered seven and a quarter.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As opposed to you said seven and a quarter and they're thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: No, they offered seven and a quarter and I'm thinking about it. (nothing from Billy) And you're thinking -- what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking I don't want to lose Damon, but I don't pay my whole infield seven million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're losing Damon?

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: For seven and a half, Billy, you can keep Johnny Damon and we can be done thinking. I have to go, my plane is boarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, don't hang up. Don't hang up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy drops the phone in a plastic container, steps through the metal detector like it's a stick-up, grabs the phone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that phone still on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the difference? 7. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faradie. Can his phone be on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you need to turn your phone off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already through. Billy grabs his phone from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven point five?

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: Seven point five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: Talk to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boras hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hitting speed dial on another number) A small emergency is starting to develop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try. Try to relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look fantastic today.

dialogues.speaker: ARN V/O
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arn. Billy. We gotta talk about Giambi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, we're losing Giambi, too?

dialogues.speaker: ARN V/O
dialogues.text: I can't talk about that now. I can't talk about anything now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can talk now. We're talking now. 8. 8.

dialogues.speaker: ARN V/O
dialogues.text: We can't talk now. I'm at a family thing. I'll call you Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to -- the Yankees?

dialogues.speaker: ARN V/O
dialogues.text: I'm talking to everybody. But not today. I'm not in today. I'm hanging up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found Giambi. Billy dials another number --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand dollars says you don't get on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY V/O
dialogues.text: Arn Tellem's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Denise. Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys are auctioning off my team one player at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in today, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I just want to send him flowers.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY V/O
dialogues.text: Flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would I send them?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY V/O
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Arn. 9. 9.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY V/O
dialogues.text: You want to send him flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to be anywhere near Hawaii.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To where he is now, yes.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY V/O
dialogues.text: Beth Israel Temple, Beverly Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airport is as close as you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tara.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY V/O
dialogues.text: Denise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Tara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I need a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day. I'll fly out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna be more than one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're losing Isringhausen too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if my luck stays exactly the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like the bell rang but you're still getting hit in the head. (hands him tickets) Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Have fun out there. 10. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm picking up a guy at the breakfast buffet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A left-handed reliever if you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ceremony is in progress as Billy arrives, plucks a yarmulke from a basket, sets it on his head and finds a place in the back row for himself and his carry-on. He listens to the boy's monotone-reading of verses. He fidgets. Taps his foot. Checks his watch. Turns to the person down the row and whispers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As attendees exit the ceremony and enter the adjacent banquet hall, Billy has cornered Arn Tellem, picking up right where he left off three hours ago in Oakland on the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arn, I don't wanna lose him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna lose him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my nephew's Bar Mitzvah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did well with his Torah portion I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. 11. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not staying in Oakland, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the Yankees offer him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's New York; you've got to give a player a reason not to play there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't pay my whole infield 17 million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 a year for seven years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stares, completely nonplussed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and twenty million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred and nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta get Steve to let you spend some money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty good advice, I should do that. 12. 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve doesn't get it. This isn't a charity raffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arn. I get it, he gets it, Jason gets it and you certainly get it. I'll talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're losing Isringhausen, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey mazel tov, Arn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arn walks away. Billy looks to his right to see a 12 year old kid standing right next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Billy Beane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a pretty serious choke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you from around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a Dodger fan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy hands the kid his scotch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, drink a lot of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and walks away. 13. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy tries, but is having trouble sitting still as he talks with Steve Schott - the A's owner - around 60 - a college player way back when. He's a successful home builder now. Models of developments lie around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're losing Damon and Giambi. We can't survive losing Damon and Giambi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isringhausen's gone, too, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can win without a closer. I can't without power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So negotiate with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have. They want more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So offer them a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have. They want more than a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what. What'll it cost - say - to keep Giambi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 for how many (years) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For one year? Billy nods. Steve smiles. And Billy knows what it means. It means, That makes it easy - there's nothing more to discuss on the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have confidence you'll find a way to make it work without them. 14. 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy. What are we? The Taj Mahal? We're a small-market team. Obviously, we can't afford Giambi at such a (price) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. He's gone. But I might - for a bit more than last year - be able to keep Damon in (Oakland) - (Steve is shaking his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more money, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't compete against a hundred and twenty million dollar payroll with a forty million dollar payroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just won 102 games with a forty million dollar payroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Giambi and Damon. We wouldn't have without them. Silence. Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ask me to be okay with losing. That's too much to ask a professional athlete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too much, Steve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a professional athlete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a professional GM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a small market team. You're a small market GM. And I'm asking you to be okay with not spending money I don't have. And I'm asking you to take a breath and shake off the loss. And then I'm asking you to get back in a room with your people and figure out how you're going to replace these guys with the money I do have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it? SCHOTT can go from milquetoast to ruthless in a blink and he just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's on his cell again as he crosses the Bay Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott. Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: What was that beep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just my phone, it's about to die, but this'll be quick - listen - I'm losing my favorite prospects, but I got you the seven point five.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: That's great. I'll get right back to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, you won't. I got it for you and we're done. Damon stays in Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: Billy - I have to talk to Johnny - obviously. It's my fiduciary (duty) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose number is that - seven point five. Mine?

dialogues.speaker: BORAS V/O
dialogues.text: No, it's mine -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yours. So make your call, but don't play me, Scott. We have a deal. I won't be a stalking horse. The word stays in the - dictionary. 16. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door pushes open and Billy comes in after his very long day. He sets his carry-on bag down. Takes out his dead cell phone and plugs it into a charger. Calls Tara on the land line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, hon. I'm gonna need another day.

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Take your time, do your thing. There are a lot of cute guys here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got my suitcase?

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, the airline sent it to Prague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, we left out of Oakland, honey... and I think the baggage handlers knew it was yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, can this get any worse?) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's cell phone rings --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta take this.

dialogues.speaker: TARA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Wish you weren't insane. Miss you. She hangs up. Billy hangs up and switches to his cell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Billy. Scott. I just got off the phone with Dan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you didn't. 17. 17.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was surprised he even called me. Because he had said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have Johnny for seven-point-five or he's not playing anywhere, because that's the deal --

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Boston just upped it to seven-seven-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's hand is already in motion to smash the phone, but in a herculean feat of self disciple, he manages to restrain himself before impact.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a deal.

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have a deal. If it's eight million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I the ugliest girl at the dance, Scott? Why do I get the feeling I'm always gonna be a quarter million short?

dialogues.speaker: BORAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm just doing my job for my client. That's all I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you played me. And you're playing me now. Congratulations, asshole. You win. Billy hangs up on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and his scouting department - ten men older than him - all former players and tobacco chewers still, each with his own can of Copenhagen and wastebasket - sitting around a large underground cinder block "war room" whose most extravagant appointment is a Mr. Coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two large white-boards dominate a wall, covered with magnetic strips with players' names on them. 18. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the left board - every player in the A's organization. On the other, even larger board - every player that may be of interest to them from the other organizations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the most complex chess board you will ever see. But what can be easily discerned are the obvious holes in the A's team - the star players they are about to lose - their names set apart from the positions they're vacating: Jason Giambi (1B), Johnny Damon (CF), Jason Isringhausen (RP).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, guys... we had a great year. We won 102 games and we only came a buck short in New York. Now the bad news... we've got three big holes to fill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's start with who we like for Giambi. We'll go around the room. Who you like, Matty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like Geronimo. (approval from the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's an athlete. This guy is big, fast and talented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six foot four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top of my list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean cut, good face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good jaw. He's the real deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five tools, good lookin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a tools guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a great swing. Natural swing. 19. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying he can't hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball explodes off his bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's exciting. When he hits it sounds like he's droppin' a firecracker at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down in the pisser you can hear that sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like Mays, Mantle, Aaron...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I asked. I asked can he hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's a good hitter, why doesn't he hit good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs a little work. He'll be able to hit. He could be a great hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... we put him up against big league competition and suddenly he'll be able to hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady moves on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Artie, who do we like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy backs off, incredulous as the scouts prattle on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like Perez. He swings like a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings like a man who swings at too much. 20. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some work needs to be done. I admit it. He needs to be reworked a little. But he's noticeable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's notable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's noticeable. You notice him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got an ugly girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugly girlfriend means no confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with Art. I like the way he walks into a room. Kid's so confident his dick gets there two minutes before he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passes the eye candy test. He's got the looks, he's ready to play the part. He just needs some playing time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, his girlfriend's a 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, if you want to talk about another Giambi, this guy could be it. Enough. Billy raises a book above the table, drops it with a dull THUD... STOPPING TRAFFIC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a suggestion, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, stop. You're talking like this is business as usual. It's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to solve the problem. 21. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like this. You're not even looking at the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We not only have a very clear understanding of the problem we now face, but everyone in this room has faced similar problems countless times before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is that we've lost 3 key players that we now have to replace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is the same as it always is; we've got to put a team together with what we've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got 38 home runs to replace, 120 rbi's, 47 doubles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, stop. The problem we're trying to solve is that this is an unfair game. There are rich teams, poor teams, 50 feet of crap and then there's us. And now we've been gutted. We're organ donors to the rich. The Red Sox took our kidneys and the Yankees took our heart. And now I'm listening to the same old shit about having a good body and being a tools guy like you're looking for Fabio. Is there another first baseman like Giambi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there? Everyone mumbles "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stop looking for one because what we'll surely wind up with is the McNuggets version of Giambi. 22. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we're gonna find 25 guys, put `em through player development, teach `em how to play Oakland A baseball. This is no time to push the panic button. This is the way we've been doing it for 150 years. Let us do our job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we try to play like the Yankees in here, we're not going to be able to play with them out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fortune cookie wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just regular wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Fabio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Billy. Clearly you have something on your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not playing fantasy baseball, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't new ideas, they disproved that years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill James was a night security guard at the Stokely Van Camp Pork and Beans Factory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks differently than anyone in baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in baseball. He's in pork and beans. 23. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't attack the man, attack the argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the room) I think he just won the argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we've been wrong this whole time about what ingredients manufacture a win? What if this whole time we thought it was the chicken that made the chicken soup taste good when really it was the onions that made the chicken soup taste good? Onions are a lot cheaper than chicken, you see what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the first idea what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta start over. We gotta rethink this thing. We gotta look where others aren't looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, we've been doing this for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't mean you're doing it right. Do you watch nature docs? You know what happens to the runt of the litter? He dies. I'm open to any solution, as long as it's not what the other guys are doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm going to Cleveland to poach an outfielder named Brandon Garcia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on -- You're going to Cleveland for a double-A guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, I've seen Garcia. He's got a bad body. It's not a pretty sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid wears a large pair of underwear. 24. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a big boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not just big, but kind of doughy. A fleshy kind of body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean like Babe Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no Babe Ruth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he walks, Billy, his thighs stick together. There's enough friction there to start a bonfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you saw him, I'm telling you, you wouldn't want to go to Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, can I make a suggestion? If you could get Ricardo Rincon... he'd be worth the trip to Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would solve our left handed reliever problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unanimous approval from the scouts --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get Rincon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll also come back with Joe DiMaggio and Ty Cobb. And who would like a FabergГ© egg? Guys, you aren't hearing me -- in what universe can we afford Rincon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking you guys to look at this game differently than you've ever looked at it before. I'm going to Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when I come back, I want you to tell me something I don't already know. I want to question everything. We've got to rethink this game. As he exits --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Grady? Nobody cares about a 102 win season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a FabergГ© egg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRACK! A ball sails well over the heads of the SCOUTS in the outfield who are shagging the batting practice flies. The KIDS in the parking lot have seen Billy play before and so know just how far back to stand in order to shag a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's at the plate, crushing pitches from a pitching machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRACK!--he sends another one sailing over the heads of the cluster of scouts.

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: BILLY, tanned and glistening with sweat, looks over to see THREE GIRLS watching him from behind the backstop. They're looking at him like he's Elvis and BILLY tries to nonchalant it but can't help a small smile to himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a great path. I love the extension in his swing and the backspin he creates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some amazing power right there, huh? 26. 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good approach, great balance. How's he compare to the others around the country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's number one. Let's just hope he's still there when we pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy'll go in the first round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scouts put the players through their paces -- sprinting, fielding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SABATINI and MARTINEZ are talking to BILLY, who's toweling off and is still a little aware of all the people who are standing nearby to watch the birth of a star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy. I'm Sabatini, Area Scout, New York Mets. Can we get a couple minutes of your time, find out more about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to introduce you to Tom Martinez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very impressive performance today. In my job as the national cross-checker for the New York Mets, I see the top 200 players in the United States. It's been a while since I've seen a five tools guy, the complete package. Your throwing ability, your fielding skills... Ed told me you had power but I had no idea it was of the light tower variety. I hope you're as interested in professional baseball as we are in acquiring you in the upcoming draft. 27. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, I'd need to talk it out with my parents, decide if baseball is something I want to do full time. I have a scholarship to play football at Stanford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Billy, we're certainly looking forward to meeting your folks and talking to them as well. And we believe in college, but that's something you can do in the winter months. You need to know the sky's the limit with your ability. You could be a superstar before you've even graduated. But to get to that level, you need to work with our people. Pro-ball is where you need to be to develop the skills God gave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike the A's, this is a franchise that can spend actual money on players, and on nice lobby furniture, which is where Billy sits, staring at a classic baseball photo that hangs in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Beane? Mark's ready to see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's counterpart in Cleveland--Indians General Manager MARK SHAPIRO--35 and about three weeks into the job--sits behind his desk in a tie and shirt sleeves like Billy. Joining them in the room are FOUR OTHERS, including PETER BRAND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Billy, what are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 million in additional payroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try Giambi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've been a hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Steve in all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supportive. Excited about rebuilding the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonds is available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how do I afford the rest of the field?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you looking for? I want to help out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you've touched the bottom of the sports industry when your opponent is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a lefty reliever and I want Ricardo Rincon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even a discussion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Billy, even if you could afford him we're not about to let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that? You've got the Venezuelan kid in North Carolina you're bringing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We dished him to Detroit. Keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well there goes my other idea. 29. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else you thinking Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have any outfielders I should be looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To replace Damon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a tough one Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who do you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys you might be able to afford? Hollins, Garcia... Coste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To replace Damon?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he healthy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a back thing, some minor surgery, but he's okay. Petey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be good by Spring Training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll do. I can give you Guthrie for him if you kick in some cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark Guthrie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Shapiro and gang review Guthrie's stats, Billy notices Peter whispering to the guy next to him. Shapiro looks around the room at the guys who don't object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much are you thinking? 30. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRUCE approaches Shapiro and whispers and steps away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. So... Garcia is going to be a no. What else are you thinking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make it work, I'll go straight up with you, Garcia for Guthrie, no kicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapiro looks to Bruce, Peter is covering his mouth with his hand but we can just barely hear him whisper the word 'no'. Bruce subtly shakes his head to Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Billy, who else you interested in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits at his cubicle absorbed in his computer until he notices Billy hovering over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Peter Brand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm special assistant to Mark Shapiro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you do? (pointing at co-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, mind your own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mostly player evaluation right now. 31. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does Mark listen to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually he rarely does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he was really listening to me in there per se.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think he was listening to Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Brand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a rat's ass about your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing from Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure what you're asking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you tell Butch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh Bruce? I told him I like Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably for the same reasons you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning what? 32. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's undervalued. You were smart to go after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes him undervalued?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is stuck. He can't bring himself to say anything. After a long beat Billy nods to him in a way that seems to say, `I understand, it's okay'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy makes a strong gesture indicating Peter to follow. Which he does. They exit the offices into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you from Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maryland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate Yale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid from Yale once blocked a trade I was trying to make. What'd you study?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Economics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just curious. Why were you so cagey in there? 33. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work for a different team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but I'm the first person in baseball who's ever talked to you this long. Right? Why is Garcia undervalued?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, truthfully, it might not be so easy to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Why's that Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might not see the game the same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? What do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've spent your life in baseball and I don't have a very traditional view of the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Pete, just say it. I'm not about to beat you up. Say what you've always wanted to say to a GM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baseball thinking is medieval. It's stuck in the Dark Ages. I have a more scientific view of the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an epidemic failure within the game to understand what's really happening. And it leads people who run major league teams to misjudge their players and mismanage their teams. They're still asking the wrong questions. People who run baseball teams still think in terms of buying players. Sorry to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, don't apologize for what you believe. 34. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goal shouldn't be to buy players, what you want to buy is wins. To buy wins, you buy runs. You're trying to replace Johnny Damon. The Red Sox look at Johnny Damon and they see a star worth seven point five million a year. When I look at Johnny Damon, I see an imperfect understanding of where runs come from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL VIDEO: The back of Johnny Damon's A's jersey as he walks to the plate to adoring Oakland fans.

dialogues.speaker: PETER V/O
dialogues.text: His batting average is ignorable. What matters is his on base percentage-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAMON swings at the first pitch and knocks it into left field for a single. He leads off first--

dialogues.speaker: PETER V/O
dialogues.text: - which in 2001 was .324. That's 10 points lower than league average, and 17 points lower than Garcia's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the next pitch, DAMON takes off for second--

dialogues.speaker: PETER V/O
dialogues.text: True, he stole some bases. But attempted steals in general have to succeed 70% of the time before they even start to contribute to run totals. In 2001 he cost you runs. DAMON's tagged out at second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a good glove. He's a decent leadoff hitter. He steals bases. But he's not worth the seven point five million Boston is paying him. You're lucky to have him off your payroll, it opens all kinds of interesting possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read Bill James, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. These ideas and this approach to the game aren't all new. In fact, some of them have been around for two decades. 35. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this approach has been around for so long, why isn't anybody in baseball doing them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a much more difficult question than how to win baseball games. Once you begin to pull at that string, your understanding of the world might begin to unravel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's in coach, staring at the night through the window, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's mother and father escort Martinez and Mets Head Scout Roger Jongewaard into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy? They're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy... Good to see you again. Obviously you're a very special player. We'd like to compliment you on your high school career, and we're looking forward to you being a part of the Mets family. Jongewaard sits at the kitchen table, speaking more to Billy's parents than Billy himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's good -- and there's premium. Your son is premium. He has it all -- power, speed, the arm. The Look -- and I'm never wrong about that. Which is why this is a premium number. He sets a contract on the table. Clipped to its top- sheet is a check. On its left-hand corner is the Mets insignia; on the right, the amount: $125,000. They all see it. A lot of money in 1980. Silence. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's been offered a scholarship to Stanford. 36. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. And that's a great accomplishment. I'm sure you're very proud of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he can accept that, go there, and then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jongewaard is already shaking his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand how important college is. I do. But what I can't do is burn a second first-round draft pick on someone who can't play for four years -- no matter how good he is. Four years is ample time for someone to get hurt. It happens all the time. So, no. I'm sorry. It has to be one or the other. To postpone four years is four years he could be in big leagues. The sooner he gets there the sooner he can reap the benefits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanford or The Money. Young Billy regards the check, and then his parents. He really doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to give him a different kind of education. This won't be his life's career, it'll be his first career. He's going to be a young guy in the business world when his baseball career is done. He'll still have his whole life ahead of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your decision, Billy. Whatever you decide is fine with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's looking out his window while holding his cordless phone. He's dialed the numbers in and just has to hit the green button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER's ringing cell phone wakes him up and he answers it. 37. 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Billy Beane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. Would you have drafted me in the first round?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After I left you ran me through your computer, right? Would you have drafted me in the first round?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a good baseball player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have drafted me in the first round?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have drafted you in the ninth round. No signing bonus. You'd have passed and gone to Stanford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pack your suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just bought you from the Cleveland Indians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY hangs up the phone. He sits all alone for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: Peter pulls into the parking lot for his first day of work, takes in the sight of the colossal, concrete relic that is the Oakland Coliseum. He's just in time to see a paint roller on a long pole laying a white stripe down the middle of Jason Giambi's giant portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER's completely converted the place. The dry erase boards are covered with undecipherable equations, algorithms and numbers and PETER, who's pretty tired now after not a lot of sleep, is in the middle of this. This is what BILLY sees when he walks into the doorway, where he slows down, stops and looks around blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you to do three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To evaluate three available players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how many did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51, I don't know why I lied just then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk me through the wall. PETER gets up and gives BILLY a tour of the dry erase boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the American League West. This year we're going to need to win between 97 and 101 games to make the post season. Here's the number of runs we'll need to score in order to win those games and here's the number of runs we can allow. 39. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make sure we're on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to re-think baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for an inefficiencies in statistics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Examine the ways that runs are scored and prevented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exploit the fact that unspectacular runs are just as valuable as 450-foot bombs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unspectacular runs are more valuable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they cost less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We believe there's a river that hasn't been fished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know it for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And because players have been overlooked because they don't rise to the standards of traditional baseball thinking, we believe that in this river, there are fish...fish who-- (BILLY lost it) Help me with--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the fish. In this room is every available player at every level of professional baseball, and somewhere in that group are 25 players that everyone has else has thrown out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An island of misfit toys. In this room is a championship team that we can afford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But let me ask you this. If our theory is right--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Math isn't a theory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's right--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If math isn't a theory--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna punch you in the kidneys if you don't let me finish a sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is right, why isn't everybody doing it? In fact, why isn't anybody doing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody once said, "It's not what you don't know that worries me it's what you know for sure that's got me scared." In the mid-19th Century in Budapest there was an incredibly high instance of mothers dying shortly after childbirth from a disease called puerperal fever. 35%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make this story less boring as soon as you can. 41. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doctor named Semmelweiss showed that if the attending physicians and nurses sterilized their hands before delivery, the mortality rate dropped to 1%.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was vilified?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was institutionalized. For suggesting that washing your hands before putting them inside someone else's body was a good idea. High functioning people can live under the spell of an inexplicable mental lapse when they think as a group. Why isn't anybody else doing it? Because they don't think guys who look like you are what win baseball games. They know it for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's find our team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter schleps his computer stuff. Sets up, plugs in, fires up. Turns an unused room into a war room with dry erase boards and computers. He installs software in the video room computer, works on a computer in his room, prints two pages of data and reviews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters and hands the two pages to Billy. Billy reviews, stands, then slowly paces as he reads. Peter stands and watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From somewhere in the outfield, we have a wide view of the darkened stadium and Billy's office, which, unlike the others, is illuminated. We can just discern Billy's silhouette as he continues to slowly pace and study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Peter walk down a long, subterranean corridor. Peter carries a laptop and a slim notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter doesn't know what to make of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they near the scouting room, Billy sees ART HOWE waiting for him outside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you a second before you get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a lot to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Whatever it is, Billy knows it can't be as dire as his other problems, but also knows that to ignore Art would be to insult him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures for Peter to go into the scouting room alone. He'd rather not, but does. The scouts, assuming perhaps he's there to make coffee, ignore him. He finds a place to sit in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't manage this team under a one-year contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you can. 43. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to put a team on the field, then I'll deal with your contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you deal with the manager's contract and then put a team on the field?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment, if a ground ball is hit to first base, nobody's going to be there to stop it from rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you it's not easy doing what I do under the cloud of a one-year contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have. And a 1-year contract says the same thing to a manager as it does to a player: There's not a lot of faith there. Which is strange after a 102-win season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you lose the last one of the season nobody gives a shit about the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on me now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on me, Art!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the kid's the new assistant general manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you about to do? BILLY doesn't answer the question, just walks into the- 44. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -and ignoring Peter - who has tried to inconspicuously plant himself in a corner - pulls up a chair to receive his scouts' report - which Grady, as always, will lead. Art wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go in Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news bothers no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get after our relief pitching problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got Chad Bradford. Right-hander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Few, if any of them, have heard of Bradford and begin leafing through their printouts and notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Submariner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one. Technically an underhander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his velocity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unimpressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he have a good breaking ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you like this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he gets people out. 45. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The left-hander hitters get a really good look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's down there. He's down there real low, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scouts aren't sure what to say, and so say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we, I think, have fared better. We have some ideas for what to do about Giambi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We trade power for speed. A rabbit for a gorilla - We go for an overachiever. A big heart in the last year his contract. Tend to play hard. We usually get a pretty good year out of them. Make up for some of the offense we lost. (puts more names up) Or the other option. Just a thought. We go for a high-maintenance guy. A guy that's a little difficult but talented. A guy like Milton Bradley. Well, not like Milton. Milton himself. Which do you want to talk about first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of them. Grady looks like a man who can't take much more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still looking to replace him; you're just saying it another way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got some trades here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do it. What we can do is recreate his value to us in the aggregate. 46. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The (what) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giambi's on-base percentage was .477. Damon's was .324. And Olmeda's - bless his heart - was .291. Add that up and you get - He points to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I point at you, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten-ninety-two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Divided by three -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're looking for. And that's what we'll find. Three players whose average OBP is -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't come out right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta carry the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still don't look right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right. The others aren't sure what confuses them more - the logic, or the guy who shouldn't be in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Peter. And that's all he's going to tell them about Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to say this delicately - but does - Peter - need to be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with this on base percentage obsession? Is that Bill James bullshit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call it Billy Beane bullshit for all I care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy takes a Marks-A-Lot, jots down three names on strips, and approaches the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So here's who we want. One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the first strip up. It reads: JEREMY GIAMBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason's little brother Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never comes home from the games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, if I may, he's had his problems on the field -- not to mention his problems off the field -- not to mention he's getting a little thick around the middle -- there's the stuff with the weed. He's at strip joints...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy could start the year with an agent and end up with a parole officer for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His on-base percentage is all we're looking at now and he gets on base an awful lot for someone who only costs $285,000 a year. 48. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't catch a ball in the outfield. I've seen him lose a ball in the moonlight. Billy puts up another name: DAVID JUSTICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten years ago he was a big name. He's going to really help our season tickets at the beginning of the year. But by June he's not going to be hitting his weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's 36!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His legs are gone. He's a defensive liability. I question whether the bat speed is still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steinbrenner is so pissed at his decline he's willing to eat up half his contract to get rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fossil. With all due respect, bringing these three guys aboard is like putting bubble gum on a flat tire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why do we want to be the ones to bail Justice out of his contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy points at PETER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets on base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got 37 free agents who are better than those guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Hatteberg. 49. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Sounds like an Oakland A already. Yes, he's got a little damage in his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some damage? He can't throw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not interested in him for his arm anymore than we wanted Giambi for his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, you're talkin' about Hatteberg at first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a career .260 hitter and the good part of his career is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say it's just starting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Billy, you'll like the sound of this... I hear Boston wants to cut him and no one wants to pick him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good news for us. He's cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me understand this. At first base you want a guy who's been cut from half of the minor league teams in the country due to irreparable nerve damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't hit and he can't field, but what can he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the piece of paper or I'm going to point at Peter. The SCOUTS consult their spreadsheets and then answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can get--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can get on base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, so he walks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets on base a lot, Rocco. Do I care if it's a walk or a hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These three players, by your own admission, are defective in one way or another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to replace Jason Giambi with not one but three defective players?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, we've all been busting our asses the last six and a half weeks to make this a better ball--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Grady, it's not a discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're all losing sight of the fact that you're the general manager. You only have to answer to ownership and God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know God followed baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he does. 51. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the scouts look over in Peter's direction, no doubt wondering if he's had something to do with their general manager's ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, I just don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, Wash. We won't be victimized by what we see anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand what you're saying about their averages, but there's something you're forgetting. None of them plays first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't forgotten that, Wash. One of them is going to have to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to have to teach him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instruct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. TACOMA HOUSE
dialogues.text: A Christmas tree. Four stockings hang from the mantle. The phone rings. SCOTT HATTEBERG gets up. He looks at it. Looks at his wife. Picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Billy Beane. Oakland A's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOTT was expecting that it would be someone else... 52. 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to invite me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm outside. I can see you in the window. SCOTT goes to the window and cups his hands against the glass to see outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two silhouettes are standing on the edge of the fairway. One of them waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH is putting out some cookies shaped like stars and bells for the late-night guests: BILLY and RON WASHINGTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves her husband with the two men but listens in on their conversation from the next room, nibbling on a cookie of her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've played catcher your whole life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I was 8. BILLY produces a baseball from his windbreaker and hands it to SCOTT. SCOTT can only manage to grip the baseball like a claw. Washington looks to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the elbow? 53. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Real good. It's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't throw at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, don't worry about it. You've thrown your last baseball from behind the plate. I want you at first. SCOTT is so thrown by this that all he can do is stare at BILLY. Then at WASHINGTON, who's shrug tells SCOTT "This wasn't my idea."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only ever played catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a catcher anymore. If you were, then mine wouldn't have been the only call you got when your contract expired at midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate it but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know how to play first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that hard. Tell him, Wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's incredibly hard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything worth doing is. Wash is gonna teach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, what about--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason's gone, Scott. 54. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking Giambi's spot at first? What about the fans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe I can teach one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fans don't run--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to SCOTT) --the fans don't run my ball club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna hate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning to BILLY) No, they're gonna hate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fans love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HATTEBERG's YOUNG DAUGHTER comes down the staircase in her pajamas, having just woken up in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our youngest daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY doesn't like to share personal lives with the players but he covers well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --yeah, I have a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY takes a contract out of his windbreaker and sets it on the table next to the cookies. 55. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a contract for you to play baseball with the Oakland A's. A copy's on its way to your agent. Discuss it with your wife and let us know. (They get up and Billy calls off) Thanks for the cookies, ma'am. We see ELIZABETH with tears running down her face...then go back to the living room--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his way out) Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of a suburban house opens, revealing a WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the door open so he can come in. As he does -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's out, but she'll be home soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Billy enters his ex-wife Sharon's house, her husband ALAN walks in, talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, don't worry about it sweetie. Here's mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan hands Sharon the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Alan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in have a seat. Want some coconut water? It's really refreshing. 56. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all set, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you benching now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't keep count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is, it's working. You look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit on the couch next to a Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got to see you since the playoffs in New York. That was heartbreaking, Billy. We were rooting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck `em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Alan, what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just wanted to say that a lot of teams don't get that far, and to make it that far is a really big accomplishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon gets off the phone and joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's great. Be here in a minute. How's the team shaping up?
