dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New beginnings. Blue horizons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read that you lost two players. Damon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghee-ambi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giambi. Wow, that's tough. That's really tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Isringhausen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just talked to her on her cell. She's just coming up the hill, she's two minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bought her a cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 12?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for emergencies. I'm sorry, we should have consulted you for that

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But actually I called you - The front door opens. It's Billy's daughter Casey - a pre teen indie-rock girl - and not a moment too soon. He's up quickly to give her a hug and to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Casey peruse guitars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want one with nylon strings, right? 58. 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like the red ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try it out over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take a seat. Casey easily fingers through a very tough spray of notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been playing a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's... that's not the way most 12 year olds play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan thinks I should have a better teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Alan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CASEY looks at him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Mom's Alan. What's wrong with the teacher you have now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan thinks I should be working more on technique so I don't learn bad habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you seem to be doing just fine to me. Do you like playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it. 59. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so great. I'm so happy for you. The most important thing in life is to find something you love and do it well. Do you like your teacher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll talk to Mom and Alan. Do you like that guitar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get it. Let's get it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's at the plate, a batting helmet snug around his head, wearing a METS uniform, as a 97 mph fastball buzzes by him and the UMPIRE calls--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striiike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY steps out of the box, taps the dirt off his cleats and steps back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A younger-looking SHARON is sitting in field level seats, looking on nervously and trying not to show it. BILLY half-swings at the breaking ball, holding his swing at the last minute. 60. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CATCHER and PLATE UMPIRE both point down to first base for the call and the FIRST BASE UMPIRE makes a fist in the air, indicating that Billy swung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striiike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Billy's out. SHARON holds her head in her hands and BILLY walks back to the dugout, passing a player with "STRAWBERRY" on his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now the quick scenes of failure become staccato--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY playing for minor league Tidewater and he grounds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY playing for minor League Toledo. He swings and pops up lamely to the PITCHER, throwing his bat down in frustration as he jogs hopelessly to first and we

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: ...Billy Beane, who's quickly establishing a new record for breaking bats, bat racks and water coolers, was actually a much-touted first round pick of the New York Mets in 1980 but the majors have not been kind to him with only 18 plate appearances in two years and this won't doing anything to help him as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY playing for the Minnesota Twins where he comes back into the dug out and throws his batting helmet down and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY playing for minor league Portland and a water cooler goes flying across the dugout and

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: ...one of two first round picks in 1980 along with Daryl Strawberry, Beane was brought up last year and sent back down after 8 at-bats so here's a second chance as Smith delivers... BILLY playing for the Minnesota Twins. He swings hard at a pitch and strikes out and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY playing for the Detroit Tigers and the bat rack gets heaved across the field and

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: ...If you're a real baseball fan with a good memory you might remember that Billy Beane was taken in the first round of the amateur draft back in 1980, separated from All-Star outfielder Daryl Strawberry by only 14 picks, so it just goes to show...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY in an A's uniform. He stands and watches a called third strike sail past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy breaks the bat over his thigh and drops the pieces on the plate. He begins to walk off. 62. 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Billy, clean up after yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy hears him but continues to walk off. TO BE WRITTEN: THE UMP TOSSES BILLY FROM THE GAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY looks up at SHARON in the seats behind the dugout but the two can't quite meet each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the subterranean video room - an even less elegant place than the rest of the stadium - someone has put up a scraggly Christmas tree. There, Peter watches a tape of a minor leaguer on the Lowell Spinners, a Single-A Boston affiliate. Billy comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd what go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatteberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can barely hold a baseball. But he's our guy now. Billy sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is Kevin Youkilis. This is the guy we want more than anyone else in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy watches the guy on the screen. He's an overweight right-handed batter with a peculiar stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't run, throw or field. But he walks more than anyone in baseball except Barry Bonds. Take out intentional walks and it's more than Bonds. He's the Greek God of Walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the TV, the batter takes another pitch just off the edge of the strike zone. 63. 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to get Shapiro to draft him last June. He said he waddled like a duck. Boston took him. Boston won't let him go yet. They're going to wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch him lay off a pitch an inch outside the strike zone. Peter gives Billy a look that says, You see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: GRADY O/S
dialogues.text: Billy? Grady has appeared behind them at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady closes the video room door for privacy. The only other person in sight is manager Art Howe, in his office in street clothes. He shuts his windowed door so Grady and Billy can talk in confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boy and I had a talk while you were in Tacoma. I didn't like much of what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You got a kid in there with a Yale economics degree and a scout out here with 29 years baseball experience and you're listening to the wrong one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't listen to anyone, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not joking. 64. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't how you run a ball club, with a computer. You know that. You're a baseball man. There are intangibles that only a scout can see in a player that you're not going to pick up with just numbers, with someone who doesn't play the game, who knows nothing about the game but how to feed numbers into a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're doing. That's exactly what we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is what baseball is, if it's not Kirk Gibson going up to the plate on two bad legs because the manager felt in his heart that he had one swing left in that body... a computer wouldn't do that. They would have had him sitting up in the stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A computer doesn't romanticize the sport. Leave that for the fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, romance and the fans, it's called a love affair with the game and it's been going on for one hundred and fifty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hurt you love affair with the game. Just because we've been doing it one way for a hundred and fifty years doesn't mean we've been doing it right. You have any idea how long people thought the sun revolved around the earth? To your eyes it looks like that's what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying everybody's been wrong? Everybody? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying everybody's been wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and I've thought so my whole life. And now we're gonna see if I'm--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --we're gonna see if you're right?! This is about you and your shit? Some scouts from 20 years ago called it wrong, okay? They thought you were a ballplayer and you weren't. As you know, it happens. Don't take it out on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not--taking it out on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to help, okay, I'm saying--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not saying anything to me right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady, you don't have special powers. You don't have the ability to look at a guy and "just know" because you're a scout with special powers. I've watched you sit at kitchen tables for years and tell the parents of a 17 year old kid, "Trust me, when I know, I know, and when it comes to your son, I know" and you don't. We're shopping in a new store--full of complicated statistical analysis and equations and I get that it turns your world upside down but on base percentage-- our best chance to score on our budget isn't getting a 6'4" Adonis to the plate, it's getting a 5'10" washout who's already at first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I speak?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major League Baseball and its fans will be happy to hand you and Google Boy your heads if you keep doing what you're doing here, I don't give a shit about friendship this situation or the past. Major League Baseball thinks the way I think. You're not gonna win. And I'll give you a nickel's worth of free advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making it impossible for yourself to get another job once Schott fires you after this catastrophic season you're setting us all up for and you're gonna have to explain to your wife and your kid why you're working at Dick's Sporting Goods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna fire you, Grady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRADY takes off. BILLY stands there a moment. On his way out, passing Art's windowed office, he exchanges a look with the manager. Billy takes a short walk to where a few of his scouts are standing around an arcade console. To the youngest one -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric. You never even played high school ball, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young scout shakes his head, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grady's gone. You're the new Head Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy turns away and is headed back to the video room. Pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to explain things to scouts. They're not programmed to get it. It's just us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Peter watches the door close, then glances back to the tape as Youkilis takes ball four and waddles down to first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Team / JumboTron photos are taken of our new A's. It's clear from the photo Billy didn't hire them to sell jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGEND: March 2, 2002 - SPRING TRAINING 67. 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy gives an interview to a SPORTS REPORTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, will the fans still come out now that you've lost Giambi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Graham. Will they listen to your insipid radio show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE MAGNANTE goes through the effort of putting on his knee-braces. Scott Hatteberg, lacing up, watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various stations have been set up at which infielders go through their warm-ups - wind sprints, arm loosening. Infielders field grounders hit by Art Howe from a fungo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy paces in the foul territory off the first base line. HIS POV: JEREMY GIAMBI missing a fly ball, DAVID JUSTICE looking tired, HATTEBERG missing the scoop. Art hits another grounder which Hatteberg botches again. Art looks at Billy a good long beat, then hits to another infielder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks up to Billy, just as - A poke off the bat sends Jeremy Giambi scrambling back like a postman trying to escape a mad dog. The ball lands behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we didn't pay him for his defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art and Washington hit grounders to Carlos Pena and Scott Hatteberg. Hatteberg miraculously gets his mitt on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way, Hatte. Pickin' Machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind a portable backstop, a guy with a radar gun gets ready to clock a trio of relievers. Mike Magnante has his pant legs pulled up to adjust knee-braces. Magnante gets up and begins throwing, increasing his velocity each time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of those broke 85. 68. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch the second pitcher - the gentle-faced kid from the locker room - Chad Bradford - step up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad I have high hopes for. Bradford overthrows his first submarine hand-scraping- the-ground pitch, and the ball sails wide of the catcher. Somebody ducks. Art Howe glances with a long-suffering look to Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just got away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch David Justice do wind sprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Justice stops, winded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the players shower and change into street clothes, Art, Billy and Washington discuss Hatteberg, who knows they're discussing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the first day of week one. There's nothing to judge yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can judge it and so can you. First base is the moon to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't to Giambi? He's the worst first baseman in baseball. What do you think of him, Wash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nicest way I can put it is, he lacks confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work with him Wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do that, Billy, but we've got Pena who can play first. And he's looking pretty good out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to make it work with Hatte, Wash. 69. 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Washington crosses the locker room to lie to Scott about how much progress he's making, he passes Magnante taking off his knee braces, and Chad Bradford sitting at his locker with a Bible in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to mention we already have a first baseman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rookie first baseman. It's not the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number 11 on the Top 100 Prospects list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lists aren't baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catchers at first base aren't baseball. Who's idea was this? Peter's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatteberg will be fine, Art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will be fine, you're right. Pinch hitting while Pena plays first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A towering portrait of David Justice has been painted where Jason Giambi's used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hardest diehard fans file under it and through the turnstiles. You know what they look like, dripping A's merchandise, radios and Sharpies, arriving so early the B.P. cage is still being dragged into place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indicate the arrival of opening day. INCLUDING: foul lines are painted, broadcast trucks plug in, the network control room fires up, ANNOUNCERS do their prep, Steve Schott lands in his helicopter. LEGEND: April 1, 2002 - OPENING DAY IN THE LOCKER ROOM: Players prepare. Magnante puts on his knee braces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... been doing it for way too long. 70. 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I first started these things? It was like a half hour process. Now I can knock these suckers out in 30 seconds, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy Giambi's boombox is on again as he and his 24 teammates suit up. 36-year-old David Justice wanders past to a soda machine. Presses a button, but nothing comes out. Tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is a dollar, mang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always been like that here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding me, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Oakland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and PETER walk through. He walks past CHAD BRADFORD's locker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Beane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Chad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not disturbing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to say thanks for the opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna work out well for both of us. 71. 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody in the major league ever took me seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big day, you won't forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to pray for you and your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER follows BILLY out of the locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOTS OF THE GAME ANNOUNCERS. KEN KORACH, GREG PAPA and GLEN KUIPER welcome the fans to opening day, discuss the A's lineup and the problems they face this season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fifteen minutes before the game as some executives have their picture taken on the field with BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, great to see you. Thanks for coming out. Got a good box? You want a picture? Sure, let me step in there. Great, big smiles now. Big smiles. Know what I like about opening day? Everyone's even. Thank you. You all enjoy the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY gets his picture taken with KIDS from an area Little League team. He's laughing and being a good host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how you guys doing. So you won? That's great. What position are you? How's your fastball? 92? Alright, should we get a pic? 72. 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and the Little League team pose with a giant donation check. The announcer then directs everyone's attention to a trophy ceremony in progress. As Chavez receives his Golden Glove award and smiles for the fans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY greeting some VIP's in their field-level seats. Throughout this we'll hear bits of talk radio.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: With the departure of head scout Grady Fuson and a roster that I'll describe as unusual, if not eccentric, you have to wonder what Billy Beane is thinking. BILLY catches a glance of ELIZABETH HATTEBERG taking her seat nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the family area, Elizabeth introduces herself to Tara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Tara. Which is yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Hatteberg. Catcher - actually first base - actually we don't know. Yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Beane? Tara nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a saint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art is talking to a JOURNALIST. 73. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they picking up your option for next year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought it up to them during the off- season, and I still do not have my option.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you frustrated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's fair to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art Howe stands mid-field as the starting lineup is announced. One by one, players join him on the field. The honor guard presents the flag as everyone stands for the National Anthem. Afterward, the players scatter to warm up for the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CROWD CHEERS as the A's take the field. Billy and Peter are at the edge of the tunnel, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm heading in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't watch the games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY shakes his head "no". PETER gestures "What the fuck are you talking about?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're miming. 74. 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm miming "You don't watch the games?!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my team. And they've taken the field. They're world class athletes who are fighting for their lives and I stand with them. Except not literally so I need you to text me what Art does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY walks out onto--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's watching the game on TV (ARCHIVAL VIDEO) with the sound off but we can hear the live crowd in the stadium. CRACK--a TEXAS RANGER hits a three-run homer and BILLY walks out of the room and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OAKLAND A hits an easy pop-up to center field and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where BILLY's on a stationary bike. His blackberry buzzes and he takes a look--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Fly out to cntr"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where BILLY's bench pressing and CRACK--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where an OAKLAND A has just hit a ground ball to the SHORTSTOP, who tosses it easily to second for the first out, and the SECOND BASEMAN throws it over to first for--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where BILLY looks at the blackberry which now says-- 75. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blackberry goes crashing into the wall and blows apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Billy and Art in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I should have made you a bigger part of the conversation, I should have had you in the scout meetings from the first day, that way you would have understood this better and that was another mistake, I take full responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what moves I make if you don't play the team the way I need them played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are out of your depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wasn't Hatteberg at first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he can't play first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my first baseball game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Hatteberg can't hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets on-- 76. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his defense--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still keeps us in the plus column and we only need to be 7 over 500.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I would have rather seen Chad Bradford in there at the end than Magnante.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about righty/lefty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about your contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you've made it clear what you think about that. This is about you doing your job and me doing mine. Mine's being left alone to manage the beer league team you assembled for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't assemble them for you, I assembled them for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to go on the road with the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't go on the road with the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I want you to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you? 77. 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to develop personal relationships. I need to trade them, send them down and sometimes cut them. You should learn how to do that by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way I'd have to cut a player is if you oh come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a player, cut me from the roster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man-up, Yale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Billy, would you have a seat for a moment, I need to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was pretending you weren't sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I am. Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the hardest thing there is to do in baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that from Bull Durham?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitting a curve ball is the hardest thing there is to do in baseball but go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been a huge part of this team but decisions have to be made that are best for the team, I'm sure you can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cutting me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just bought a house here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? That's all you have to say? My kids just started at a new school, they made friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's--I'd leave them in school, you don't want to take them out in the middle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you you or the player?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm me. You're talking about kids and schools and you should've been out of the room three minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't I tell them that they'll always be a part of the A's family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes me feel so good I'm thinking of burning your house down with you in it. These are professional baseball players. You just do it. "Peter, I need to let you go. Jack's office'll handle the paperwork." 79. 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rather get one bullet in the head or five in the chest and bleed to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are my only choices?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on the road with the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy Giambi discreetly mixes a highball from a cache of hotel minibar liquor bottles as he watches his favorite movie on a portable DVD player, The Natural. DAVID JUSTICE is sitting next to PETER, who scrolls down stats on his laptop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come your boss doesn't travel with the team?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't like to mingle with the players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes us easier to cut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER doesn't say anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna make some moves if we keep losing. PETER gives a small "Yeah" shrug...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come soda costs a dollar in the clubhouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy likes to keep the money on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soda money? 80. 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER doesn't say anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where on the field is the dollar I pay for soda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy watches the T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV - PENA taking his place at first.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: The A's begin their first road trip of the season having dropped 7 of their first 11 games at home and their schedule doesn't get any easier from here. If there's a bright spot it's rookie first baseman Carlos Pena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy turns off the T.V., gets beeper updates as he works out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy drives.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES V/O
dialogues.text: With the A's getting off to a miserable start/13 of their last 20/17 of their last 25/etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's waiting for someone. HE'S WATCHING THE A'S GAME BY THE GATE. A PASSENGER, also watching the game, recognizes Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, aren't you Billy Beane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be at the game? 81. 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CASEY emerges from the gate, sees her father before he sees her and runs to him. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, honey... I'm glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and PETER are throwing a ball through their office doors on either side of the hallway--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a big enough sample yet. I want to wait until we play more games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY watches the game from the office T.V. He sees --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID JUSTICE grounds into a double play to end the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Justice hits into the 6-4-3 double play to end the game... The INDIANS trot on the field to high-five each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casey sits at the table as Billy scoops ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want strawberry or vanilla?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could only have one ice cream for the rest of your life, which would you choose? 82. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanilla. Definitely vanilla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting. Chocolate sauce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup. A beat. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... if you could choose between the power of invisibility or flight, which would you choose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight. Yeah, I'd wanna fly. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd want invisibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. People wouldn't notice me as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't you want people to notice you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you could sneak up on people. Or eavesdrop on their conversations. You could be a spy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My teacher's kinda mean. She doesn't like us to ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of teacher doesn't let you ask questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, right? Mom was mad, too. She thinks maybe I should be home schooled. 83. 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you miss your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But the other kids are mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are always going to be bullies. Try not to let them get to you. But let me know if it's becoming a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question? Are you still chewing tobacco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, it's terrible. Look, I promise I'll quit in November if you promise not to worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkie swear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkie swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theoretically, when we've played more games the numbers will become more

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theoretically?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scoreboard shows the A's down by 1 in the 6th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Art trudges toward the mound to pull his starter, he touches his left arm. Magnante emerges from the pen - and Peter, up in a VIP box, flips open his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is saying goodbye to CASEY. 84. 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Billy's Blackberry chimes. He ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, did we talk enough this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything. Did we talk about the things you want to talk about, did we have fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing it right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're worrying about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look like I'm worried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cause you're getting on an airplane and those things crash all the time. Will you please stop worrying about your father? You're a kid, I can't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Can I worry about the airplane now though?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FLIGHT ATTENDANT approaches --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a slightly awkward moment and CASEY isn't sure whether she's supposed to hug her father again and so they do a sort of half-hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. BILLY watches her go off with the attendant, feeling like it was an unsatisfying visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his blackberry-- 3-2. Magnante in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! WHY IS HE IN THERE?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVERYONE in the area stops to look at the madman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the people looking at him) No no. I'm alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy runs the warning track with a small radio that he turns on long enough to follow what's happening, and switches it off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the following, we hear a cacophony of radio and TV VOICES tumbling into each other-- 86. 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The A's have fallen to 19-25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGNATE giving up a save-blowing hit while BRADFORD sits in the bullpen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Oakland A hits into a double-play, strike out, caught stealing, picked off first, a lop-sided scoreboard, half-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parking lot is a vast, empty black sea with just two pin-points of moving light. Headlights. Billy drives around the lot like a downhill skier with nothing in his way -- his daughter's mix-tape playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy lines a single to right, but is so slow he's almost thrown out at first. Art Howe glances at his bench coach, Ken Macha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art Howe is the only manager in baseball who has to think about pinch running his leadoff hitter. Down in the Visitors' pen, Chad sits with Mike Magnante.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't not do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do it? Every ball park's different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take that into account and adjust the distance of my steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly seventy-four, from the pen to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get that looked at, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEAM in the dugout, hanging their heads during a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter erases the percentage of games left they need to win and writes in a higher number and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's listening to the radio.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER V/O
dialogues.text: -- after Sunday's 11-0 rout. Now, having dropped 13 of 16, the A's are a game away from being swept at home by the AL East last place Baltimore Orioles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as we follow Billy's truck from Oakland over the Bay Bridge into San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter. Guys, give me some idea of what's going on out there. 88. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, it's a team of probabilities, and we're gonna need 162 games to tell that tale in a nascent form. It's phase one, we're evolving and we feel confident where we're heading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 out of 17 games. 3. We're getting crucified in the press. What makes you think this is gonna turn around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I believe in what we're doing. I believe the numbers. I believe the record doesn't accurately reflect the team and where we're going to be at the end of the season. Peter and I feel very strongly that we need to stick to the game plan, and you can tell your partners to start booking their tickets to the playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, look, you've got guys who are nearly crippled, who couldn't get hired as an usher in a ballpark now playing on the team. Give me something I can go back to these guys with and feel like I have the confidence that you're gonna turn these things around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect you asked me to build a team with shoelaces and gum wrappers and we've done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't done it yet billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it will pay off. Stick with us. Suffer the blows. Listen, life with no money means we're gonna have to suffer a few embarrassments along the way, but we are okay in the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, there's a lot of money at stake here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a lot of people with vested interest in seeing this be successful. I've given you a lot of flexibility. When are we gonna start to see a change in these results? Schott sits back at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a date, give me a time frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we expect to be mid July All Star break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our goal and our expectation by the All Star break is to be within seven games of first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll keep us in the hunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that would be this working exceptionally well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 within 500. By July. And what's going to keep us from getting there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. We're 3 for 17 right now. You've got to be able to give me a little bit more to go back to my partners with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you hired me to do this job and that's where we're going to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's go buy Barry Bonds, then. This is the team we've got and this is the team we'll win with. 90. 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, put yourself in my shoes. What do you imagine is going to happen if things don't turn around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very clear, Steve. If I put myself in your shoes, I'd spend another 20 million on the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have another 20 million

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just kidding, Steve, I'm just kidding. We've got the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta be honest with you, Billy, I wish you had a little more worry and a little more fear. Because things aren't going in our direction right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 162 games Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope the next 30 are better than the last 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right fellas. Let's go try and win one. We're in May, we've got til July.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The A's take batting practice. LEGEND: May 23, 2002

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ART, as he always does, is watching not from the railing but from the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY walks into the dugout without saying hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not gonna lose three at home to the Orioles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want Dye in right, Justice DH-ing, Pena on the bench, Hatteberg at first and anyone but Magnante first out of the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want Pena on the bench?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. So that you can play Hatteberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatte - as opposed to the guy who's going to win Rookie of the Year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Hatte - as opposed to the guy who gets on base less. Pena getting voted Rookie of the Year and the A's making the playoffs are two entirely different--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pena's not just the best first baseman on the roster, he's the only first baseman on the roster and the most valuable member on this team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not according to, what do you call `em, facts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me--gets on base more than Pena. 25% more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fielding doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does matter and Pena only has one error in 70 games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only is that number statistically insignificant but it's also subjective. It measures what someone did against what someone else thought they were supposed to do. 92. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of the conversation? I've heard enough of the conversation and I disagree with you, plain and simple. Moreover, I strongly believe that you're in the middle of experiencing some sort of personal crisis and you seem indifferent to the fact that you're taking a whole organization down with you. I'm playing my team in a way I can explain in job interviews this winter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some As players arrive in the dugout, causing Billy to hold his tongue. He simply says -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatte, not Pena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game plays silently on the TV as Billy lifts weights. Not wanting to watch but not being able not to, he looks at the screen to see Pena trotting out to first base ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Orioles' bench clears to high-five the players coming off the field. The game is over, and, obviously, they've won. The A's exit their dugout to the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Art crosses to his office, he sees Billy waiting inside it with a towel around his neck. He hesitates, then goes in and we follow him. Billy says nothing, but his silence is worse. Art has to break it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just one game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the point, you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is always tomorrow's game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the point - as you said - is to win. I don't like sharing the cellar with Texas, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear FUNK MUSIC begin to play in the distance. 93. 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing the best I can with what I've got. I'm playing the players I've got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy lets himself out and walks down the hall to the locker room - regards Jeremy Giambi -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not even aware of Billy. It's just like any other night as far as Jeremy Giambi is concerned. He dances to a CD of funk music as he dresses, until he becomes aware of Billy standing there, and smiling, he kills the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting swept by the Red Sox at home. Having Long lead off the ninth with a triple in a one-run game and not being able to score a runner from first with nobody out, is that fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what the fuck are you having fun for?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what losing sounds like. He heads out.

dialogues.speaker: PETER V/O
dialogues.text: ...point 3-5 below the AL average field which isn't bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy? 94. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter rattles off player stats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I missed my exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy takes the next off ramp and as LIGHTS FLARE on the windshield, we transition to ANOTHER TIME, YOUNG BILLY

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Billy and his wife drive home from a game in silence, their infant daughter Casey asleep in a car seat in back. Sharon regards Billy's hands, clutched too tightly to the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you thought about what you might do if baseball doesn't work out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was too abrupt. 95. 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If baseball doesn't work out. Have you thought about what you might do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game's only been over for three hours, I haven't had that much time to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe real estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be honest, if I don't make it in baseball I don't think I'm going to be able to afford much real estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a slump, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying every scout was wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kind of saying it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey...don't you think you should divorce me now while you're young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHARON looks at him... then her eyes go to the window. 96. 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a science experiment fails in a lab, things blow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems are the price you pay for progress. - Branch Rickey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy shoves a wad of Copenhagen under his lip as he and Peter walk-and-talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's seated at his desk. Peter reluctantly dials a number from a list, the number across from the Phillies' GM's name. It connects on the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed. Billy. I need some help on defense and I'm willing to trade Jeremy Giambi for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you (aren't) -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Peter; to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you got? 97. 97.

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: Let me think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Jeremy's doing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleaning house.

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: Maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe what?

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: No. Mabry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on. (put the call on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Runs hot and cold, Billy. Impossible to know what we're going to get. He's a crap shoot. He's exactly the kind of player we're not looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) He'll be fine, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: Why do I get the feeling you're picking my pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not picking your pocket, you're picking mine. Giambi's name alone is worth more than Mabry.

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: You realize - 98. 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. His career is stagnant, to put it nicely. Can we say it's done in theory and start drawing up paperwork?

dialogues.speaker: WADE V/O
dialogues.text: Okay. But -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he was going to say something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter. Rule Number 3: When you get the answer you're looking for - hang up. That's done, and in a minute Pena's going to Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you want to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art can't put him at first if he's playing for the Tigers and I want Hatte in the lineup tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should think about this. You're upset and this is - this -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a very hard move to explain. People are going to think you've lost your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that a problem Peter? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make an emotional decision Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Dombrowski's on 3. 99. 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy picks up the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you have to shake it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, PeГ±a's going on the blocks, you're my first call... because he's making the rest of the team look bad... He's going to be rookie of the year...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not eager to help but...) Probably an all star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's an all star Dave... (winks at Peter,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more like he's creating self-esteem problems for the other guys... No, I'm looking for a reliever and some cash... Ok... five minutes Dave, I'm not waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to slow it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, PeГ±a is an all star. If you dump him, and if Hatte doesn't work out, you know, this is the kind of decision that gets you fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you worrying about my job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You worried about my job or yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried about yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you should be worrying about yours because if this thing we're doing don't work... neither of us have jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's probably true. 100. 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In which case I'm a 44 year old guy with a high-school diploma and a daughter who I'd like to be able to put through college one day. (lets it sink in) You're 25 years old with a degree from Yale and a pretty impressive apprenticeship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we're asking the right question. I think the question we're supposed to be asking now is, do you believe in what we're doing or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a problem that you think we need to explain ourselves. Don't... to anyone. I'm going to see this through, for better or for worse. Just tell me, do you project we'll win more games with PeГ±a or Hatteberg on first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's close Billy but theoretically Hatteberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we talking about then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That works. Great. There's just one more thing I need. I don't want the guys paying for soda--I want you to stock my soda machine for three years. Uh huh, uh huh, great... then that's a deal. Billy hangs up. He stares at Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. You gotta tell Pena to pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to tell Pena he's been traded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a man. 101. 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Jeremy? Am I telling him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks into the locker room. Sees Pena talking to a couple of other players. He approaches Pena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get a moment with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe we can talk over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk awkwardly to the players' lounge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat. They sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, um, Carlos, you've been traded to the Tigers. This is the number of Jay Palmer, their travel secretary. He's expecting your call. He'll help you arrange travel to Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pena sits and stares at him. It's excruciating for Peter, awkward, until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pena just takes it. Picks up the number and leaves. 102. 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy knocks and lets himself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't start Pena at first tonight, you'll have to start Hatteberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go 15 rounds, Billy, the line-up card is mine and that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line-up card is definitely yours, I'm just saying you can't start Pena at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am starting Pena at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, he plays for the Detroit Tigers now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You traded Pena?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along with German, Hiljus and Jeremy Giambi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are outside your fucking mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art stares at him in a silence broken by Jeremy Giambi knocking on the open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy, come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy jots a phone number on an A's Post-It and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Ed Wade's number. You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art looks sick. 103. 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillies General Manager. Real nice guy. Give him a call - he's expecting it - say hello - then talk to Futterman about arranging a flight for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight. To Philadelphia. Billy gets up and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a real pleasure, Jeremy. I mean that. You're a great ballplayer and great guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy, not sure he heard right, looks at the Post-It in his hand as Billy escorts him to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy leaves. Billy looks at Art from the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adkins is gone, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're killing this team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art? I can do this all day long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Art notices Peter, who had been lurking by the door, eavesdropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not looking at anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went along with this? You agree with this bullshit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred percent. 104. 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pena cleans out his locker. Several players stop by to say goodbye. Tejada --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your head up, okay? It's part of the business. You're gonna be a great player, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let this bother you at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad Bradford --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, brother. Take care and... God bless you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Hatteberg --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best first baseman here. It's not right, Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Hattie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and PETER stride through as the team is getting dressed for batting practice. The place quiets down as BILLY comes in. They've all heard the news and they've never experienced a move like this in their careers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scottie H.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go out and field some grounders. 105. 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY looks around at the PLAYERS, who are looking at Billy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody, listen up. You may not look like a winning ball team. In fact, you look nothing like a winning ball team. But you are one. So play like one tonight. You'll get further instructions tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID JUSTICE hits a single up the middle as the runners on 2nd and 3rd round the bases to score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's blackberry buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sngl up the mdl--2 rns scr"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy talks to Chavez and Ellis. Peter stands nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more bunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more bunts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunt is an out. You're paid to avoid outs, not make them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunt isn't an out. It's a sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunt is for pitchers and weak hitters. You're not a pitcher, Chavvie, so what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until the third out, anything can happen. After the third out, it's over. You gotta protect your outs like they're your children. Every out's precious, don't give `em away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another thing -- you should see more pitches. We wanna get into their bullpen. Deep into their bullpen. We want to see 100 pitches by the end of the 5th inning. You wanna get your at-bats off their 10th and 11th pitcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want us to walk more. How much more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least once every ten at bats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Triple-A Sacramento's only 80 miles away. And there's no flights. (as they look to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at him. Here's the deal. I'm not interested in what you think you know about baseball, or what you think I don't know about it. I'm not interested in guts or heart or determination or anything else the fans or your mothers love about you. I'm interested in you getting on base. If you do that, we win. If you don't, we lose. And I hate to lose. I hate to lose more than I need to win. There's a difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Peter give advice to Dye and Byrnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every at bat is like a hand of blackjack. Every card that's dealt, your odds completely change. For instance, every first pitch strike, your batting average goes down about 75 points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 points. Every first pitch ball, it goes up about the same amount. So you gotta lay off the first pitch. 107. 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First pitch curveball or first pitch fastball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First pitch period. When you swing at the first pitch you're batting .140.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to see more pitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many pitches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every starter, we want to see 100 pitches by the 5th inning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... 5, 6 pitches per at bat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, Hatteberg drained 38 pitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Byrnsie, you're hackin' at everything. You're all squirrely out there. Wait for your pitch, man. This is a war of attrition. There's no clock on this thing. Wait `em out. Let them make the mistakes. And when your enemy's making mistakes -- don't interrupt them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter advises Durham as he works out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basically, these are all your at bats. This is you versus righties, you versus lefties... and then, of course, all your count knowledge, okay? In an 0-0 count you're batting .290. In an 0-1 you average .238. In a 0-2, .159. When you're 1-0, you're batting .324. Understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, it's a lot of math. When your first pitch is a strike, your batting average goes down about 70 points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it's a ball, it goes up about 30. If you draw a ball on your first pitch, you're unstoppable. If you strike on the first pitch, you might as well be jumping off cliff. I'm trying to get you to lay off the first pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm a first pitch hitter. I like to swing at fastballs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the way you've been trained. But it's a habit we'd like to break you from. We're trying to design the game to your strengths. This has nothing to do with you being a great hitter -- you're a great hitter. We just want to get you on base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if I get my pitch, I'm gonna swing at it, no matter what the count is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about you crushing the ball out of the park. I just want you to lay off anything that will result in a strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll have to watch some film and take a look at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. The video room is open to you any time, I'm always available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and PETER with a group of players around the card table, post-game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- But seriously. Make him use up all his bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, make him work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... Mr. Beane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's fine. 109. 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, make it Mr. Beane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Beane --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm screwin' with you, Haddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we just don't steal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I do. That's what you pay me to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I pay you to get on first, not get thrown out at second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get thrown out much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hit on 17 at the blackjack table, but if I did, the odds would be the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've actually gotten caught 6 out of 17 tries this season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get 11 of 17. That's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just handed them an out. Protect your outs like they're your children. There's no clock on this game. Until the third out, anything can happen. Get on base and let the next guy move you up. Pass the torch, pass the torch. We're like a machine. A run making machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JUSTICE and HATTEBERG prepare food --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your biggest fear? 110. 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baseball being hit in my general direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave. I've been thinking... I want you to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna teach me something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen a GM talk to players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never seen a GM who was a player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, man. I know your routine. It's a patter, it's rap, it's for effect. That's okay. But it's for them, it's not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're special?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're paying me 7 million bucks so I guess I am a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact I'm not paying you 7 million bucks, David. The Yankees are paying half your salary. That's what the New York Yankees think of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're paying you three and a half million dollars to play against them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is news to Justice, he doesn't show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going with this, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're almost 37, Dave. Almost as old as me. Let's be honest with each other about what we each want. I want to milk the last ounce of baseball you have left in you, and you want to stay in the show. So let's do that. I'm not paying you to be the player you used to be, I'm paying you to be the player you are now. You're smart, you know what's going on here. I need you to set an example for the younger guys. Take a leadership role.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justice just studies him ... then nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Billy starts to leave, but has one last thought for him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- the Yankees are coming to town. If it were me -- I'd want to take that three point five and shove it up their ass. But I'm a competitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy exits. Justice calls after him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I got a couple World Series rings. I think I'm a pretty good competitor, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want another one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID JUSTICE takes ball four from a Yanks pitcher, tosses his bat to the side and trots down to first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEJADA is on first and taking a big lead toward second. He wants to steal it bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tejada taking a big lead off first, eyeing the steal--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY watches with two or three TEAM EMPLOYEES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it, Migs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And CRACK--a base hit sends Tejada to 3rd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's blackberry buzzes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sngl to lft. Frst and thrd--nobody out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels of the team jet lift off--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV is on as BILLY and PETER work, seeming more and more like mad scientists who are getting closer and closer to splitting the atom.

dialogues.speaker: GREG PAPA OR RAY FOSSE, (TV)
dialogues.text: What is happening in Oakland?!! The A's have won seven in a row and 15 of their last 19. You got to hand it to Art Howe. He's managing this unorthodox team in an unorthodox way. They are not bunting. They are not stealing. They are just winning. And Art Howe is the reason. 113. 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard 7 in a row. Billy clicks off the TV and it's very quiet. Billy is scrolling down numbers that show trends and comparisons of all of the A's relief pitching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you show me righty-lefty matchups for the division and overall versus Mariners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter reaches over and with a few clicks produces new columns of numbers, upon which Billy darts his eyes as he scrolls through them. Finally -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and heads out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY walks through the clubhouse, shouting locker room shoutouts to PLAYERS as he walks by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing back down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
