dialogues.text: That smell is getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on it, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splitting the plate in half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both sides. (to Hudson, playing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huddy, you gotta mix it up tonight. Trust your slider. 114. 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others) You guys stop distracting him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chavvie -- you couldn't hit that shit with a boat paddle last night. You gotta see more pitches. Patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Billy crosses through the weight room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey David --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great at bats. Really. Quality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY knocks on Art's door -- something we haven't seen him do before. ART can see BILLY through the window blinds and is a little surprised at the courtesy of a knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. BILLY does. He's going to try to do this nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. You knocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, and I hope you take it as a show of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see. 115. 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've won 7 in a row, what am I doing wrong now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnante's having some head problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's 37 and he's got three blown saves in two weeks. Everytime he winds up he's thinking he's about to throw the last pitch of his life. So he grips it a little hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I know my bullpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you do. Yes you absolutely do. No question about it. Except not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we have a lead late in the game and they have runners on base, I'd rather not see Magnante out of the bullpen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make that decision when the time comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you should do. Baseball's a game of situations and you should make the decision when the time comes. Except you should make it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bring Magnante out if we've gotta hold a late lead with runners on. He's 37, he's scared shitless of being the guy who blows this winning streak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think a lot of yourself, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I......think the regular amount of myself. Magnante on the other hand, he doesn't think very much of himself at all, and when he tightens up we've got ourselves an adventure. So I'd like to see Chad Bradford out of the pen tonight when we're in, let's say, just to make it easier for you, any situation. Righty/lefty, two outs, no outs, the umpires have decided we're going to finish the game by playing darts, whatever. Bradford's the first guy out of the pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ART regards BILLY for a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could've coached you up, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you went as far as you could have? 117. 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I meant. Play Bradford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY steps out of Art's office into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game plays on TV as BILLY bench presses. The A's are up by three runs in the ninth inning but the Indians have a runner on first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the tunnel, BILLY can hear the crack of the bat and a collective groan from the stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY holds the barbell in the air--frozen--as he simply looks at the T.V. and sees the silent images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ART HOWE walking to the mound, tapping his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGNANTE heading to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think BILLY's going to trash the weights, but he simply returns the barbell to the bracket, sits up and watches the silent images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGNANTE mops his brow, squints for the sign, winds up and makes his pitch. It misses low for ball four and PEDRO walks to first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy lays back on the bench, breathes, then unmutes the T.V. and we hear -

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (FROM TV)
dialogues.text: Magnante has quickly let two on base for Lee Stevens who's the go ahead run for the Indians in a game that Oakland appeared to have put away. And then - BILLY sits calmly...waits for it...and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --BILLY nods his head at the inevitable. 118. 118.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (FROM TV)
dialogues.text: That ball is deep....way back...three run homer for Lee Stevens to put Cleveland ahead in the ninth inning... BILLY can hear 40,000 people booing their lungs out. He takes a moment, then grabs his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FANS are booing as ART makes his way to the mound to take MAGNANTE out. BRADFORD makes his way from the bullpen and takes the ball from ART. ART turns to head back to the dugout but slows as he sees a strange sight: BILLY is standing at the dugout rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plate UMPIRE notices and follows Art's line of sight. He sees BILLY and walks over there ahead of Art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be in there, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY doesn't move. He just watches ART as he comes into the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLAYERS are watching to see what's going to happen. BILLY puts his hand on ART's shoulder a second as he says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just nod a little bit--not too much--like I'm assuring you you didn't just make a calamitous vocational decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players and coaches only, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring the umpire-- still quietly to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that in about four seconds-- BILLY sees one of the nearby TV cameras pivot over to catch this conversation--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --yeah there it is. We're the lead story on Sports Center now so let me be brief. First of all, that was an awfully costly fuck-you, wouldn't you say? 119. 119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second of all, genius, those boos? They're for you. Drink up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me this game back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As BILLY passes MAGNANTE he pats his back before we--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio is on and the ANNOUNCER is telling us--

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (FROM RADIO)
dialogues.text: ...after giving up the lead on a three run homer off Magnante, the A's came right back to win it in the bottom of the ninth with another three run homer by Miguel Tejada. And the A's have won eight in a row!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the early-bird fanatics arrive - players arrive at the players' entrance -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnante walks into the A's locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, standing at the door, surveys the room, his eyes moving from player to player as they're hanging up their street clothes. The team's equipment manager, pouring himself a cup of coffee, glances over -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want one, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm good, Voos. Thanks. 120. 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voos wanders off. Billy keeps looking at the players ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEGEND: July 31 - TRADE DEADLINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy comes in sticking some tobacco under his lip and, like a shark that knows it could die if it stops moving, doesn't through the entire scene --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne, get Shapiro on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you thinking Rincon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's lost faith for the season. I think he's gonna dump him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardcore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wait as Suzanne dials the Indians' GM, staring at the speakerphone that sits like a little island in the middle of the conference table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapiro on two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark. Billy. Let's be honest. A premiere setup man is not going to get you any closer to the playoffs.

dialogues.speaker: SHAPIRO V/O
dialogues.text: Are you referring to Rincon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a luxury you can't afford.

dialogues.speaker: SHAPIRO V/O
dialogues.text: And you can? There's half a million on his contract and at least one other suitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By at least one, you mean one? Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: SHAPIRO V/O
dialogues.text: I'd rather not say. 121. 121.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Stares down Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think we can get for Magnante?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (continues to stare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left on Venafro's contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne -- get me Sabean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can get San Francisco interested in Venafro, Shapiro's only got one buyer for Rincon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete gets busy on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabes. Billy. You like Venafro. I can let you have him for almost nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SABEAN V/O
dialogues.text: (smelling a rat) Why would you do that, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm amazing.

dialogues.speaker: SABEAN V/O
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want is a couple of bucks and a sweetener. Throw in, say... 122. 122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy snaps his fingers at Peter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: SABEAN V/O
dialogues.text: I like Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you don't. I don't even like him. I don't know why I'm doing this -- but let's do it anyway. Venafro for Michaelson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson. See, I don't even know his name.

dialogues.speaker: SABEAN V/O
dialogues.text: I'll think (about) --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it and call me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Shapiro back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Pete stare at each other in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two!

dialogues.speaker: SHAPIRO V/O
dialogues.text: You can't afford him, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure about that? I get the impression the market for Rincon is softening. I could be wrong. Call whoever's interested and make sure they're still interested. And call me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. 123. 123.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Mets for Venafro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just offered him to the Giants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne -- Steve Phillips! Get me Steve Phillips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete works his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between Bonds, Nen, Kent and Snow, they're never gonna do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just need them to cool on Rincon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillips on two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve-O. Billy. I hear you're looking for a left-handed reliever. What do you think of Venafro? I can make it quick and easy for you.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: What's the angle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No angle.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: Who am I getting fleeced for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts him on hold. Peter is already scrolling through the Mets' farm system, his eyes darting around the stats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bennett maybe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six. 124. 124.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-six and in Double-A? Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan? No. Cerda? No. Furbush?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furbush?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eckerton? Eckerton. Eckerton, that's the guy. Billy punches the phone off hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eckerton.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: Eckerton? I like Eckerton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know who Eckerton is. The phone on Pete's desk rings. Peter answers a second blinking line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: Is Venafro hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not hurt. He's fine. This is just a situation for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Steve.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: Last couple of times out, he got hammered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on with Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not his fault. We misused him. 125. 125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve Schott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to hold. (to Steve Phillips) Look. Steve. Here's the deal. I'm being straight with you. I'm getting Rincon. It's a done deal. It's done.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: I heard the Giants --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the Giants want Venafro. And I told them they can have him for Michaelson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but I'd rather deal with you. Because you can give me Eckerton and two hundred and twenty-five thousand cash and the Giants can't. Billy's look to Peter says, Doesn't hurt to ask. As they listen to silence on Phillips' side of the call --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand it's impolite to keep you holding.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIPS V/O
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Think. But whoever calls me back first gets Venafro. He hangs up. Looks for the blinking light that belongs to his owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could have the power of flight or invisibility, which would you choose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invisibility or flight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invisibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Casey said. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have total access. Besides, everyone else would choose flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why isn't anybody calling? The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shapiro's on two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy picks up. Listens. Fist pump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Lemme talk to my owner. Call you right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillips or Schott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I call Phillips back? Schott. Tell him I'm on the other line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter dials. Billy can't sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Schott, it's Peter Brand. Sorry I left you on hold. Billy asked me to call you back. He's on another line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him we need two hundred and twenty- five grand for Rincon. 127. 127.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy says he needs two hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars for Ricardo Rincon. Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I added the please. (listens; to Billy) No. Billy thinks intensely. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'll pay it, but when I sell him next year for twice that, I keep the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy says he'll pay for Rincon himself, sell him next year, and keep the profit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter listens to whatever Steve Schott is saying, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he'll pay for Rincon. High five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! Shit. What are we forgetting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Shapiro!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as he grabs his cell phone and hits speed dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, never mind! (beat, then into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark. Yeah, it's Billy. Here's the deal. I don't want Rincon pitching against me tonight. Tell him to change his clothes. I got you the money and I accept your gratitude. It's done. He hangs up. Fist bump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta let someone go. It's Mags. It's gotta be Mags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call not it. 128. 128.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy dials an extension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art. Billy. The good news is Ricardo Rincon's heading over to the clubhouse. The bad news is you got to tell Mags he threw his last pitch for the Oakland A's last night.

dialogues.speaker: ART V/O
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, no.

dialogues.speaker: ART V/O
dialogues.text: No, as in no. I'm not doing it. You do it. You did it, so you do it. Art hangs up. Billy slams the speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the phone's fault. Suzanne, we're gonna need a new speakerphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta catch Mags before Rincon comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy comes through the clubhouse past his team suiting up to where Magnante is adjusting his knee braces next to his locker, and sits with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy. I know I've been struggling lately. But we're coming into the home stretch, and I promise I'm gonna turn it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I need you to stop getting dressed. Magnante isn't sure he heard right, but the silence tells him he did. Eventually -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traded? 129. 129.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for the crap news. I know it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike. I can't have 26 guys in the clubhouse. Magnante nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Billy gets up to leave. As he exits, he sees Peter enter with Rincon, standing with his new uniform in his arms, looking like a prison inmate. Oops. Billy joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ricardo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hola, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hola. Hey, I know this must seem a bit sudden, but the Oakland A's have been trying to get you for a long time. You're gonna love it here. The guys are fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muy divertido.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pitch tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you're gonna pitch tonight. But you're on our team tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I no wanna pitch tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. So... where you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veracruz, Mexico. 130. 130.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're a lot closer to home. Why don't you hang out there for five menudos and we'll get you a uniform and everything. (to side room) Hey guys, clear the room, huh? Say hi to Ricardo Rincon. As the other players file out and say hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, Tara and Casey at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tara and me were thinking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad... Tara and I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tara and I were thinking about going to Point Reyes to the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me go, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll work on my grammar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, then) Dad... are you going to lose your job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Where did you hear that, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The internet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not going to lose my job. Don't go on the internet or watch TV or read the papers or talk to people. 131. 131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to people, I'm just reading stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. You don't believe me? Ask Tara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not (losing his job). Your dad is a brilliant man. He's the best GM in baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But say that you did -- just saying -- would you have to move away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey. Absolutely not. And even if I did, I'm not going anywhere. I told you not to worry about me. People say a lot of crazy things and they don't always know what they're talking about. It's just gossip. Like gossipers at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't always believe what you read. Sometimes you need to scratch underneath the surface and find who the authority is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And once you do find out who the authorities are, ignore them at all costs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can always ask your dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's fine, honey. I'm not going anywhere. The only way I would lose my job is if someone was to give me a better one. Don't worry about me, okay? Dad knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkie swear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinkie swear. 132. 132.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of the AL West standings over A GAME BEING PLAYED--from the start of the season until now--the teams shifting positions as the "games-out" and winning percentage numbers change like an adding machine, too fast for us to really follow, but then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The calculations abruptly lock and we're given enough time to understand where we--and Oakland--are after 120

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AL West GB WP Seattle --- .610 Anaheim 2.0 .593 Oakland 4.5 .571 Texas 21.5 .427

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER V/O
dialogues.text: The A's begin this road trip on a 10 game winning streak, picking up two games on the Mariners and the Angels, and it should be noted this is their longest winning streak in six years heading into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PITCH TRACKING CAMERA mounted in center field. ZOOM IN to the lens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits with Hatteberg, reviewing his hits on a monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a chart of what you should and shouldn't be swinging at. These circles represent different pitches. Red is hit, blue is out, yellow's missed or foul, green is chased, white taken. This is you versus Conway. What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm chasing a lot of high and outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red is where most hits happen. That's where you want to be swinging. You don't want to be swinging at the junk at the top of the strike zone. We'd rather take those strikes, `cause you're not going to hit `em out of the park. And you're good about that, patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now you're averaging about 4 pitches per at-bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 per bat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and that's great. One of the reasons why we love you. You're draining a pitcher's pitches. Now, guys like Bonds and Jason Giambi average a little over 5. That's top tier. Does this chart make sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'll get on base more if I lay off anything high. This is awesome. So you have a breakdown of this from every game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every game. Your instincts are in the right place. This isn't something they teach you in little league. This is something fundamental we're looking for -- how to wear out a pitcher's arm. If you're about to face Conway and wondering what you should and shouldn't swing at, come in here and watch how you're tending. You can click on any one of these pitches and watch it happen. Pretty great, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me some of the stuff I'm chasing up high... TIME LAPSE of hundreds of at bats registering and changing modalities to produce graphs and numbers. PULL OUT to reveal we're now in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Bradford review footage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter analyzes the data with Billy as they throw a ball back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody thinks the first pitch is what's most important, but it's not. It's the first two out of three pitches that matter the most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The difference between 1-2 and 2-1 is the difference between a scrub and an All Star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're saying if we can get our guys to lay off the first pitch it'll put us in the driver's seat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sort of extra discipline in the first three pitches will help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A game is on TV in the background. Billy makes various comments the the screen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a problem right there. Terrance jogging to first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Justice. That's what we pay you for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad Bradford, you deceptive son of a bitch, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a pain in the ass, but that Giambi gets on base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another train of thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatteberg once had 18 walks in 30 at bats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My whole career I only had eighteen walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually... 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we have QUICK SCENES OF BILLY TAKING PLAYERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Migs, let's make a deal. I'll pay you fifty bucks for every away fastball you hit to opposite field, but you've gotta pay me fifty for every one of those you pull. 135. 135.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tejada immediately starts thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERRANCE LONG is working out. Billy pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, T. Did your car get egged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I just got an e-mail from the culprit. He said he was tired of paying good money just to watch you jogging around the bases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does that have to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, man. Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy exits. Long calls after --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who brings eggs to the ballpark anyway?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Mecir walk down the hall with the smelly stain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you're not fooling anyone but yourself out there. You're falling further and further behind. In your mind, what's the problem? Mecir mumbles something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't understand you with your hand over your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Billy. It's just, the smell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that. And it's growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at the stain in silence. Finally -- 136. 136.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna grab a shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatteberg in the clubhouse. Billy enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Scottie. What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I'm hurting the team. At first base I'm making a lot of errors. I'm gonna cost us a hundred runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16.5 actually. But as a hitter, you will create 70 runs. 70 runs wins us an awful lot of ball games. I can live with that. Can you live with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate that, but I know you're just pulling those numbers out of your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pulling them out of Pete's, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And another thing. When a guy reaches first base, be social.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Social?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a greeter at the Gap. A guy steps into your office, chat him up. You're well read, you went to college. Have some fun out there. Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scottie, you deserve to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER is erasing the percentage of games left that they need to win and writing in a LOWER number-- 137. 137.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More information. TIME LAPSE PHOTOGRAPHY of all of the changes to the board over the following two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Twins vs. the A's. A TWINS PLAYER stands at first, stoic. Scott figures "What the hell?" and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you guys getting up to tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The focused Twins player looks at Scott like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bed by ten o'clock. Game time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sore, man. Beat up. Day in, day out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where d'you guys go next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Houston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Houston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever get up to Boundary Waters up there in Minnesota? It's beautiful. I went on a trip up there. Fishing trip. Caught some walleye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott chatting with a DIFFERENT TWIN on first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mankevich" is polish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack! The ball's in play. It's thrown to Hatteberg, who tags out the stunned player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DIFFERENT TWIN is on first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: University of Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you guys getting up to tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what the city's about -- San Francisco. What are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Depends on if we beat you today. Probably celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So my GM says I gotta be more social. What was your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jaqcue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Scott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Scott?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good. You got kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack! Hatteberg catches the ball, making another out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The standings graphic shows the A's have just moved up into a three-way tie for first place-- 139. 139.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oakland's offense has exploded, scoring 40 runs in their last four games and extending their streak to 17 in a row which is an American League record going back to 1954 and just three shy of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AL West GB WP Oakland --- .619 Anaheim 4.0 .591 Seattle 4.5 .586 Texas 22.5 .450

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAD BRADFORD smokes the last batter on a called third strike to end the game against the Twins, and the TEAM rushes in to congratulate him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY looks down at his blackberry, sees the result and makes a small fist pump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would have thought in April I'd be saying this: The A's won their 18th game in a row, that's two-shy of tying, three- shy of beating the American League record-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --where the energy is electric. AL West GB WP Oakland --- .633 Anaheim 3.5 .609 Seattle 7.0 .583 Texas 25.5 .449

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: This is something special now and far be it for me to jinx it by saying how many consecutive games the A's have won-- 140. 140.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Well you said it not me. Tickets are torn and purses searched as record breaking numbers of fans pour into the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: None of the Oakland fans in their cars down there have forgotten the A's inglorious history-making choke in Game 5 of the ALDS last October and tonight--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a tomb. The PLAYERS are getting ready without music or chat. Justice steps up to deliver a pre-game pep talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen up fellas... bring it up real quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got some older guys on this team, we got some younger guys on this team. What we got right now is a chance for everyone to make history. I don't want to get sappy and corny, but this is what we play for. We've been playin' real good for 19. Let's get 20. We get 20, they can't take that away from us until they do it themselves. Guys that are starting tonight, keep playing like you've been playing. Guys not starting, be ready. Huddie, you got the ball -- shove it up their ass tonight. Let's play some ball! Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 4, 2002 Kansas City Royals at Oakland A's

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: --one game shy of 20 consecutive wins, they have a shot at redemption. How rare is it to win 20 games in a row? This rare: No American League team has ever done it. 141. 141.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY heads east on 580. His cell phone rings and he hits the speaker button for the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me the score, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON V/O
dialogues.text: It's me, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin', leggy.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON V/O
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon?

dialogues.speaker: SHARON V/O
dialogues.text: You hangin' in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's silence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Go into real estate". What a stupid thing to say. BILLY didn't even realize until that moment how much he wanted to hear her say that...He's not sure what to say back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate that, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SHARON V/O
dialogues.text: Good luck. Casey wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: CASEY V/O
dialogues.text: Are you on your way to the stadium?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm on my way to Visalia to see our minor league team. 142. 142.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad - turn around. You have to see the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll talk to you later, sweetheart. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, drives a little longer...letting what Casey said sink in. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he turns on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: Tim Hudson is carving through this Royals line-up and at the end of three, it's the A's 11 and Kansas City nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sees the sign for the next exit coming up. He makes a decision and quickly crosses to the right, just making the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is striding through an underground corridor which is echoing with the cheers of 55,000 fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY emerges from a tunnel to a sight Billy's denied himself for 138 games: The lit-up ballpark with a game in play. From the field, we see Billy finding his place in the seats behind home plate. Peter is already there. 143. 143.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY'S POV OF THE SCOREBOARD: 11-0 at the bottom of the 3rd. Unfortunately the idyllic moment is short-lived as Dye strikes out swinging and the teams swap places. The A's take the field with TIM HUDSON pitching. Billy looks around. He sees the scoreboard, a FAN with a big funky cowboy hat, the charged-up crowd in the stands, it's like the Coliseum at Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IBANEZ of the Royals singles to center field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDA of the Royals singles to left field. But the Oakland fans are still jubilant and do the wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a big error from Tejada puts runners on 1st, 2nd and 3rd (MAYNE, Ibanez and Randa).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if we've entered the Twilight Zone, it becomes twilight and LIGHTS GO ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEE BROWN of the Royals singles to right, bringing Ibanez and Randa home, and Mayne to 3rd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ibanez and Randa high-five each other at the plate, passing Billy as they head to their dugout. Okay, the Royals are on the board now: 11-2, but just barely. Until

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEREZ of the Royals singles to center field, bringing Mayne home. Then TUCKER of the Royals doubles to left field. Justice makes an embarrassing fall trying to catch it, and Brown and Perez score. They high-five and pass Billy as they leave the plate, the second time he's seen that, and suddenly the Royals have 5. Reaction shot CLOSE-UPS: Justice, Tejada, Tucker on 2nd, Art Howe, the Royals' dugout, a pitcher's conference with Peterson and Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally Billy, who WALKS OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE SWEENEY of the Royals singles to left-center field - Neither Justice or Long get it, it lands between them. And they have WORDS. 144. 144.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Randa makes a sloppy single to left field... this one goes between Justice and Tejada.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of A's at bat: Hernandez grounds out, DURHAM strikes out, Mabry grounds out... A stunned A'S FAN stands up with his arms out in a "WTF??" gesture. While the A's are still up, this is excruciating for the fans.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: Kansas City's scored five and Oakland's lead is down to six as Art Howe comes out to the mound to pull Tim Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art Howe comes out of the dugout, gives the signal for "underhander," takes the ball from Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER V/O
dialogues.text: He'll go with the submariner, Chad Bradford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see SHOTS OF FANS in the sold-out stadium experiencing the height of tension and excitement in sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad Bradford comes off the bullpen mound to relieve Hudson, and begins counting his steps -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three, four -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad arriving at the mound taking the game ball from Art, who we see is genuinely supportive and encouraging to Chad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad finishing his warm-up pitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it is to be in need and to have plenty. I am content. I can do all things through Christ who gives me

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is just as tense as the fans. 145. 145.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself but to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Chad, let's see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAD walks Mayne. An angry fan throws toilet paper onto center field, the one thing Long manages to pick up. The crowd grows anxious. CHAD's submariner pitch to the next batter, DEE BROWN, walks him. BROWN trots down to first and there are now two runners on. Some FANS have to cover their eyes. There's a pitcher conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art Howe simmers in frustration. He signals Rincon to warm up. The fans aren't happy either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ORDAZ of the Royals grounds to Tejada, who throws home for the force, and misses. Now it's 11-6!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howe pulls Bradford. Rincon throws a controversial strike out. The Royals batter, TUCKER, protests, and fans go crazy BOOING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown scores, 11-7 now, Royals chipping away that lead,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howe pulls Rincon. Tam comes in to relieve him. Sweeney's up. In rapid succession, we seem him battle off TEN PITCHES of Tam. He's got two strikes on him, more toilet paper flies on the field, Bowie comes in to warm up which Tam sees, then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWEENEY HITS A THREE-RUN HOMER TO MAKE IT 11-10! This is excruciating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOWIE is already gone. KOCH is on the mound. There's a Royal, PELLOW, on 2nd. According to the scoreboard, it's 2 outs, 2 strikes. If Koch throws a strike, the game is over. The fans are fucking feverish. ALICEA of the Royals singles to left and Pellow scores. The game is now TIED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In their dugout, Royals GLOAT. 146. 146.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ended the inning, but in the A's dugout, Koch slams the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scoreboard shows us that it's still tied in the bottom of the ninth. Nobody's out. DYE grabs a bat and walks to the plate. Then, inexplicably, Howe turns to-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hattie. Grab a bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOTT HATTEBERG actually points to himself and mouths, Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOTT pulls a bat from the rack and heads to the on-deck circle. He only manages a warmup pitch or two before -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy is watching on a muted television as he sees Dye fly out to right field. As Hatte approaches the plate, he kills the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ROY STEELE's booming voice echoes:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OF GOD
dialogues.text: Pinch hitting for Eric Byrnes--Scott Hatteberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott's wife, ELIZABETH, watches from the VIP seats. She clutches her face. SCOTT lets the first pitch go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art Howe looks like he can't stand it any longer. In the dugout, Koch looks like a psychopath ready to kill. SCOTT steps out of the box to catch his breath. He steps back in and stares at the exact spot in space he thinks the pitch will leave the pitcher's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pitch. SCOTT swings. 147. 147.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crack! 55,000 erupt. The A's leap to the front of the dugout steps and watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the ball ascending on a strong trajectory, but before we can know for sure where it's headed, TIME SLOWS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's sitting on the floor with his back against the wall, trying to breathe. He looks like he's in pain. He can't move. He hears the crowd ERUPT outside. His Blackberry buzzes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "hatte homered. a's 12, ryls 11"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy flips on the TV. With sound off, he watches silent images of his team swarming the mound in (archival footage) mixed in with Art Howe celebrating with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is going crazy. ELIZABETH is screaming as she watches her husband get mauled by his teammates at the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's still contemplating making AL history as celebrating players flood into the locker room just outside. Billy looks through a portal on the door. He's trapped in here now. He crosses into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed with players, coaches and news crews. There's no champagne spraying but they feel like they won the World Series and in fact have done something much more rare. Billy is trying to make a fast unnoticed exit. After pushing through the crowd, he walks outside of the club house into the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where the players' families and wives are waiting. Billy sees ELIZABETH HATTEBERG walking toward him-- 148. 148.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Beane? I'm Elizabeth Hatteberg. We met at my house last Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank me? Thank you. Whatever you put in those Christmas cookies, keep-- ELIZABETH starts to cry--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what it's like to have everyone think you're a failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY doesn't say anything but of course he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...You never thought that, and that's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the worst possible

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he knows I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY takes this in a second...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah he does know you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's talked to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all over now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your husband just took a Jason Grimsley two-seam fastball and parked it in the upper deck in left field for a pinch-hit walk-off home run in a record breaking game. Go tell him about it. ELIZABETH looks at him a moment...and then starts crying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's okay now, just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELIZABETH goes off to find her husband. BILLY sees PETER standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilligan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and TARA are eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, man. I spend the season trying to reduce it to numbers and we won on romance. Suddenly it's the Natural with Hatteberg. Scott Hatteberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've seen Elizabeth's face when it went right over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She showed up afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a big moment for them. You know everyone wrote him off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't. You found him and you put that together. 150. 150.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It was beautiful. But you know... it's not gonna mean a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's upset. She knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the thing -- we changed the game. We got this year, maybe next, then they're gonna catch on. This is our moment. I want to go the distance. I wanna shove it up the Yankees' ass. Not just the Yankees, but... these guys deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deserve it. Honey, 20 games. It's a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, it's just a record. It gets buried in some book. Come on, tell me who won 19? I don't even know. It's 4th place at the Olympics. Any other team wins the World Series this year... great. We're still in the record books. But if we win, we've changed the game. We've put it on its head and shoved it up their ass. If we don't, they're gonna erase us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same shot as at the beginning: the Coliseum from high above, only this time the final game of the division series is being played at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minnesota Twins at Oakland A's The camera pans down the huge scoreboard. It's excruciating. The numbers on the board tell us it's been an incredibly close game but the A's are losing by one run in the bottom of the ninth with two outs and nobody on. 151. 151.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Durham stands in at the plate. Strike one to the Durham as we hear the venerable voice of ESPN's Joe Morgan, who's speaking post-game.

dialogues.speaker: JOE MORGAN V/O
dialogues.text: The flaw in the A's thinking, and this comes from the top of their organization-- is their failure to comprehend you have to manufacture runs in the post season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durham fouls off a pitch. Strike two.

dialogues.speaker: JOE MORGAN V/O
dialogues.text: You have to steal. You have to bunt. You have to sacrifice. You have to trust in small ball, not Billy Ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durham swings at the fastball and connects, but it's a pop fly to second which a TWINS INFIELDER easily nabs. The PITCHER throws his glove in the air and the CATCHER runs out to the mound as the rest of the Twins run to the middle of the field to begin their victory celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Durham turns away and heads back to the dugout. The A's have lost the series.

dialogues.speaker: JOE MORGAN V/O
dialogues.text: They think they've devised a science to win games. They think it resides in a computer. They thumb their nose at fundamentals. At tradition. At Baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harrowed by the defeat, PETER stares at the TV, listening to Joe Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: JOE MORGAN V/O
dialogues.text: They're bean counters in Oakland. That's bean with an "e" at the end. They're card counters at the blackjack table who forget the house always wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter SMASHING a wooden chair to pieces with a baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, in exhaustion, his eyes glued again to the screen watching shots (ARCHIVAL VIDEO) of euphoric Twins reveling and A's stunned at their misfortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LOCKED-OFF SHOT begins to slowly move towards the pile of celebrating players on the mound and as we near, the sound begins to fade and the PLAYERS BEGIN TO DISAPPEAR, as do the FANS and ALL OCCUPANTS OF THE COLISEUM. DRIFT i an empty stadium, towards the dugout, where the last of the CLEANING CREW brooms the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES down a dimly lit cinder block corridor, and finally into the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where we discover a solitary figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera comes to settle on the Oakland A's player, still in uniform, hours after the game has ended, sitting with his face in his hands. After a long, deep breath he sits up and we discover that it's Billy, 10 years prior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, still in uniform, walks down the long corridor that leads to the GM's office, his cleats clicking on the concrete halls.

dialogues.speaker: ALDERSON V/O
dialogues.text: This is weird, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's standing in front of the A's GM wearing his uniform pants and a t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a politician quitting a campaign to become a staffer. Do you even know what a scout does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been scouted since I was 15. 153. 153.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're ready to say, "I'm not a baseball player"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a baseball player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to do this? Pete nods. Billy calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzanne? Get Schott on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever been to Boston? The speakerphone rings. Billy answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk about the Red Sox.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I heard. John Henry reached out to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But I haven't spoken with him yet.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want your blessing before I do.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, how am I supposed to react to all of this? You're under contract, Billy. You extended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Steve, but I'd like to talk to them. I want to see what they have to say.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You're asking me to let them talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. With your permission. 154. 154.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, I can't do that unless I know Peter is in place as my GM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm not letting you take him with you, and I have no idea if he's willing to stay if you aren't here. How do I even know I can come to terms with him, given the extremely disadvantaged bargaining position you're putting me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think you'll agree this is a great opportunity for him. I can't believe he's not going to make a deal. Peter is frozen. Neither Steve nor Billy are acting like he's even in the room.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you want out of your contract, I want their whole team and a lot of cash. We've invested in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't asked to get out of my contract, Steve, I just asked if I could talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I said I won't give you permission unless I know I have Peter! You can't leave me with a vacant front office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then talk to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOTT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All right. You know what? I've made it a point never to stand in the way of a man wanting to make more money. They made the call, the genie's out of the bottle. I had faith in your judgement when I named you GM; that's why I did it and I have faith in it now. Good luck, Billy. 155. 155.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy hangs up. A long beat. Peter looks at Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't see that coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should think about staying. You're one of the architects of this thing, it belongs as much to you as it does to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little overwhelmed right now. I think I need to process what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take the day off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy regards culinary treats presented fancifully in a towncar that transports him to Fenway Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We establish the famous home of the Red Sox before finding BILLY standing on home plate. He looks around at the historic stadium...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Billy Beane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN HENRY, the new owner of the Boston Red Sox, is shouting at him from the owner's box. BILLY gives a kind of wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due respect to the Coliseum, but this is a ball park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is. It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever play here? 156. 156.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY swinging hard at a pitch in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a shame. Let's walk the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and JOHN begin a stroll around the perimeter of Fenway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm sorry I kept you waiting but believe it or not there was snow on 84. The second week in October. The car turns on to Yawkee Way and it's 53 degrees and this. How can there be an entirely different weather system here than there is three miles from here? Is that global warming or a sign that there's no such thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that Billy Joel song? Oh the snow it was falling from Stockbridge to Boston. And the hilltops seemed something because of that frosting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's James Taylor and I'm certain those aren't the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well whatever, it was snowing from Stockbridge to Boston so I'm sorry I'm late. We'll have lunch in a little bit but why don't I have some coffee sent up. (he's already got his cell phone open) Denise? (back to BILLY) We've got espresso, cappuccino, latte, we've got a machine that makes whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got free soda. 157. 157.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you have some coffee in there for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He snaps the phone shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and John admire the view. DENISE sets down a tray of coffee and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her birthday and I need to get her a present but she's usually the one who does that for me so do you have any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scarf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like wool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I meant something that women wear with, you know, a decorative --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure! Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where would I get something like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, no disrespect, I just lost in five for the second year in a row -- give her a bowling ball for all I care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve Schott told me he's offering you a new contract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why'd you return my call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the Red Sox, and I think I can help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can do something about the Curse of the Bambino. I heard you hired Bill James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why it took someone so long to hire that guy is beyond me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because baseball hates him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money buys a lot of things. One is the luxury to disregard what baseball thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be nice. (beat, then) I was grateful to get your call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks at BILLY a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For 41 million you built a playoff team. You lost Damon, Giambi, Isringhausen and Pena and you won two more games without them than you did with them. And we begin a slow push-in on BILLY... this is the first person in baseball other than his assistant who doesn't think he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won the exact same number of games as the Yankees but the Yankees paid 1.4 million dollars per win and you paid two- hundred and sixty thousand. Yes, I want you to be my General Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're taking it in the teeth. The first guy through a wall always gets hurt. But those are dying voices. Any GM that doesn't tear down their team and rebuild it using your model is gonna be a dinosaur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN's taken a piece of paper out of his pocket and slides it to BILLY -- 159. 159.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first offer. BILLY opens it, looks at it for less than a second, and looks back up at JOHN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy looks out at the Boston scenery. He steals a glance at the paper in his hand, John's offer, pensive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy comes into the locker room and gives it a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits at a table. A baseball SLAMS down in front of him. He looks up to see where it came from. PETER is standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. What the hell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was Boston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're giving me Youkilis, Billy. 160. 160.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I ever do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Billy, Schott's going to want something in exchange for letting you out of your contract and I want Youkilis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what is that, your GM voice? You can't have him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cash. And a player to be named later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already have my job. What else do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't leave me much choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Henry make you a good offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he make you a good offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete just stares at him. Finally, Billy reaches into his pocket, takes out the folded piece of paper and hands it to Peter. Peter looks at it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He offered to make you the highest paid GM in pro sports. 161. 161.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I love the Red Sox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I've never heard you say you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why am I doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not doing it for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing it for what the money says. It says what it says to any player who gets big money: that they're worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The offer says that. The money itself is redundant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made one personal decision based on money in my life and I swore to never do that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not going to Boston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all over the news that it's a done deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this place. What a dump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I so wanted to win here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've already won, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Pete, we lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't given yourself time to get over it, it's only been three days. 162. 162.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not even over last year yet. I don't get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something in the video room, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really can't look at video right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not much more than a home movie but you'll get the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Visalia Oaks and their 240 pound catcher, Jeremy Brown, who's scared of running to second. This was in a game six weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL hits the remote and the tape starts. The quality is poor and the camera is focused only on Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's gonna start him off with a fastball low and in because he hasn't read the book on our guy and doesn't know that low and in is where he eats. Jeremy takes him to deep center -- We see JEREMY BROWN connect and the ball fly off the bat but the camera stays on JEREMY running to first. PAUL slows down the picture with the remote

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and he knows that if he runs it's a stand-up double and he's running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he's gonna do something he never does. He's gonna round first base, he's gonna take the turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me he's safe at second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Because right here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEREMY slips and stumbles to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- is what he's always been afraid of. It's all he can do to get himself back to first. JEREMY has been scrambling in the dirt to get safely back to first base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first base coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he laughing? I'm gonna fire that guy, why the hell is he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEREMY's looking around the field now, looking at his own dugout. We can't see what he sees but he's confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now Jeremy finds out why. Watch his face because this is art. He's just found out the ball went 60 feet over the fence. He'd hit a home run but he didn't know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And JEREMY's face explodes into a smile. He slaps hands with the first base coach and begins his trot around the bases. BILLY stares at this. He takes the remote and backs it up a little so he can see Jeremy's face again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can anybody not be romantic about baseball? 164. 164.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a metaph--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was a metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a hell of a baseball season, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Island of Misfit Toys. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Billy's mind begins to go elsewhere. No resolution, no decision, other than to get up and wander on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stops in front of a door, checks to see if it's open, it is and he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Stands and takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stands and takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stands at area from which a mysterious smell still emanates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy haunts the field, talking to himself. Eventually he stands at the plate, and has an imaginary at bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete watches Billy from the pitch tracking monitor as he argues with an imaginary ump before hitting an imaginary inside the park home run that ends with a slide into home

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy wanders over to the pitcher's mound. Lies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His POV of perfect sky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY's driving along and listening to the continued DRONE of talk radio criticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY keeps listening a moment, then reaches in the glove box and pulls out a CD marked "Dad's Mix".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY slips it in the CD player. The sound of the radio immediately snaps off and the momentary silence is soon broken by CASEY's VOICE--

dialogues.speaker: CASEY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad. I picked these songs out just for you. And then the first track on the CD comes on (SONG TBD).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And BILLY smiles. He continues on down the freeway into dusk, as--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Justice at the plate. As he takes ball four and trots down to first, the image freezes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legend: David Justice retired after the 2002 season, leaving baseball with a team-leading on-base percentage with most walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott Hatteberg, looking comfortable on the infield dirt finally, dives for a line drive - freeze. 166. 166.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legend: Scott Hatteberg played three more seasons with the A's, then signed with Cincinnati in 2006 - as a first baseman. He retired in 2007.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chad Bradford goes into his windup from Mars. As his hand scrapes the dirt - freeze. Legend: Chad Bradford went to the Red Sox in 2005. In 2008, he was traded to Tampa Bay who went on to the World Series with a payroll even lower than the A's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin Youkilis, in a Red Sox uniform, shimmies at the plate. As he lays off ball four and the umpire points to first - freeze. Legend: Boston never traded to Billy - or anyone else - their Greek God of Walks, Kevin Youkilis. He was part of the historic World Series Championship Red Sox of 2004, and is still with the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, in a Yale Bulldogs uniform, scoops a grounder to second. As he throws out a Yale Bulldog - freeze. Legend: Peter Brand left Oakland in 2004 to become the General Manager of the Dodgers. He's now with the San Diego Padres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy - 18 years old - in his Mount Carmel High uniform, takes his stance at the plate with the supreme confidence of youth. The pitch comes. He swings. And as his bat makes contact - freeze. Legend: Billy Beane is still the General Manager of the Oakland A's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coliseum's floodlights switch off and the green of the grass darkens -
